description: ** Look for our partner PassionIT Group's information in the Episode Files section of the first episode for curriculum, exam offers Codes for offers are available to members and in the download in the second episode** The Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) was created to help businesses manage their IT operations more efficiently and reliably. The ITIL framework provides a collection of practices that businesses can choose to adopt that focus on aligning IT operations with the goals of the business. These practices range from creating new service offerings to day-to-day operations and managing incidents. Many organizations choose to follow ITIL because it prevents them from having to "reinvent the wheel" when it comes to IT processes and operations. The ITIL Foundations certification is designed to introduce the candidate to the general processes in ITIL and how they can be used to benefit an organization.

episodes.description: ** Download the Episode Files for information available from our partner PassionIT Group ** In this episode, Daniel and Terry give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming ITIL Foundation series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed. For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group info@passionitgroup.com.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.365
[NOISE] In this segment, we'll be

2
00:00:04.365 --> 00:00:09.325
taking a look at what we can expect from

3
00:00:09.325 --> 00:00:14.446
our upcoming ITIL Foundation series.

4
00:00:14.446 --> 00:00:17.785
Now, Terry, you've joined us, so
graciously, and we thank you for that.

5
00:00:17.785 --> 00:00:21.195
Why don't we go ahead and start with
who is the intended audience for

6
00:00:21.195 --> 00:00:22.455
this upcoming series?

7
00:00:22.455 --> 00:00:23.638
>> It's a good question.

8
00:00:23.638 --> 00:00:26.575
ITIL covers a wide range of topics.

9
00:00:26.575 --> 00:00:28.110
This is the foundation course.

10
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:32.220
So it actually can target anybody
that works in IT, whether you work

11
00:00:32.220 --> 00:00:36.830
in operations in a day to day function or
whether you are an executive

12
00:00:36.830 --> 00:00:39.830
that works at the strategic functions and
all points in between.

13
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:43.920
A lot of organizations adopt ITIL

14
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:47.520
to expand the organization
across various functions.

15
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:51.140
So if you are an IT,
this is the topic for you.

16
00:00:51.140 --> 00:00:54.480
>> All right, well if you're looking for
the Cisco class, this isn't then, right?

17
00:00:54.480 --> 00:00:58.570
So now that we know who is
actually looking at this

18
00:00:58.570 --> 00:01:01.870
why don't you give us a general idea
of what we can expect from the series.

19
00:01:01.870 --> 00:01:07.660
>> Sure, one way I describe this to lay
people that ask me, what do you do.

20
00:01:07.660 --> 00:01:09.960
And I tell them I'm an ITEL instructor.

21
00:01:09.960 --> 00:01:13.580
It's effectively, business skills for
IT people, right?

22
00:01:13.580 --> 00:01:19.000
It describes ITIL functions as
they relate to the business.

23
00:01:19.000 --> 00:01:23.570
And I can give you a brief overview,
here on the slide here.

24
00:01:23.570 --> 00:01:28.550
In that, it starts with
an overall description of ITIL.

25
00:01:28.550 --> 00:01:32.630
But then it digs in to service strategy,
it moves to service design,

26
00:01:32.630 --> 00:01:35.150
service transition, service operation.

27
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:39.630
And then wraps it up with fundamentals
of continual service improvement.

28
00:01:39.630 --> 00:01:44.950
So as you can tell it is
covering a wide expanse of detail

29
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:49.420
at a foundation level which means that
you're going to get a superficial

30
00:01:49.420 --> 00:01:53.160
rendering of the entire ITL course books.

31
00:01:54.180 --> 00:01:58.150
>> All right and anything specific that
you want to say about what we're going to

32
00:01:58.150 --> 00:02:00.900
learn in the series itself?

33
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:03.200
>> Yeah,
I think the way to approach this is that,

34
00:02:03.200 --> 00:02:05.390
understand you're gonna have
some self study, right?

35
00:02:05.390 --> 00:02:08.150
And while you'll get a lot
of good information and

36
00:02:08.150 --> 00:02:13.450
conceptual hooks to hang this knowledge
on when you go through the episodes.

37
00:02:13.450 --> 00:02:15.360
Your self study is gonna be important and

38
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:19.350
the primary way to do your self study
is to focus on some practice exams.

39
00:02:19.350 --> 00:02:24.170
And there's two available,
I'm showing you an example now,

40
00:02:24.170 --> 00:02:27.130
happens to be called sample papers,
they're practice exams.

41
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:30.520
Sample Paper C and
I'm just scrolling through here.

42
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:35.310
You can see that the exam ends up being
40 questions, this mimics the real exam.

43
00:02:35.310 --> 00:02:39.450
So obviously, they're not the exact
same questions, but this is very similar

44
00:02:39.450 --> 00:02:44.380
in format, and complexity and it covers
the same concepts as the real exam will.

45
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:45.620
And you've got two of these.

46
00:02:45.620 --> 00:02:50.160
And these also are accompanied
by the answers to the exam, so

47
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:55.270
if you take sample paper C you also get
another handout that has the answers and

48
00:02:55.270 --> 00:02:57.880
the rationale for
why that answer is correct.

49
00:02:57.880 --> 00:03:02.360
And at the foundation level the rationale
is It's because it's correct a lot,

50
00:03:02.360 --> 00:03:03.880
it's the right answer, right.

51
00:03:03.880 --> 00:03:05.920
Not necessarily a full blown explanation.

52
00:03:05.920 --> 00:03:10.370
So, I think be ready to do your
self study these two practice

53
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:14.460
exams are gonna be the key methods of
that sell study and review, all right.

54
00:03:14.460 --> 00:03:15.970
And you can use the answers and

55
00:03:15.970 --> 00:03:20.730
the rational to reinforce what
you've learned through the episodes.

56
00:03:20.730 --> 00:03:22.700
>> I guess the final
question I would have for

57
00:03:22.700 --> 00:03:25.820
you is can you tell us a little
bit about the exam itself?

58
00:03:25.820 --> 00:03:29.230
What can we expect as test takers,
the time constraints,

59
00:03:29.230 --> 00:03:31.310
questions, signing up,
anything you can think of?

60
00:03:31.310 --> 00:03:36.420
>> Sure, we'll there's 40 questions on the
exam and you get 60 minutes to take it.

61
00:03:36.420 --> 00:03:39.690
That average about a minute and
a half, well exactly a minute and

62
00:03:39.690 --> 00:03:41.080
a half per question.

63
00:03:41.080 --> 00:03:45.050
So it's a pretty good clip, you just
roll through the exam and answer them.

64
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:48.870
And it's the type of exam that it's only
testing at, it's testing your knowledge.

65
00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:51.550
It's not testing your
ability to analyze and

66
00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:54.790
implement ITIL,
it really is a lot of recall.

67
00:03:54.790 --> 00:03:57.240
So, there's a lot of wrote
memorization involved and

68
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:01.870
conceptual awareness as opposed to
deep dive analysis and synthesis.

69
00:04:01.870 --> 00:04:03.490
Right, so, it's pretty quick.

70
00:04:03.490 --> 00:04:05.300
There's only one right answer for
each one.

71
00:04:05.300 --> 00:04:06.470
You gotta get 26 out of the 40,

72
00:04:06.470 --> 00:04:10.580
so the bar is not super high,
65% that turns out to be.

73
00:04:10.580 --> 00:04:13.670
26 questions correct out of 40 and

74
00:04:13.670 --> 00:04:16.200
you are considered certified
at the foundation level.

75
00:04:16.200 --> 00:04:17.675
That's how the exam looks.

76
00:04:17.675 --> 00:04:21.570
And the downloads that are available
if you look around the screen.

77
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:24.890
You'll get a choice to
download the episode files.

78
00:04:24.890 --> 00:04:28.530
Those practice exams are zipped
up in there so you can get those.

79
00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:31.780
Including the answers and the rationale.

80
00:04:31.780 --> 00:04:34.480
There's the veritable goody
box of other things, too.

81
00:04:34.480 --> 00:04:38.480
There's instructions on how you can
join the ITSM community of forums.

82
00:04:38.480 --> 00:04:41.200
So you can come in, log in,
get to the forum and

83
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:46.170
have conversations with experts
like me and other instructors

84
00:04:46.170 --> 00:04:49.980
as well as other candidates, the people
trying to get the certification.

85
00:04:49.980 --> 00:04:52.599
So you can post your questions and
get good answers there.

86
00:04:54.350 --> 00:04:58.190
The course materials,
affectedly the slide deck if you will,

87
00:04:58.190 --> 00:05:02.670
it's not in powerpoint formats and
pdf format, but you get what I'm

88
00:05:02.670 --> 00:05:07.890
presenting in paper form,
there's ways to get access to that.

89
00:05:07.890 --> 00:05:12.290
Instructions for how to get there, and
also instructions for how to redeem

90
00:05:12.290 --> 00:05:16.890
discounts for your actual exam, as well
as to buy books, like if you want to buy

91
00:05:16.890 --> 00:05:21.315
the ITIL library books, those five core
publications or some pocket manuals.

92
00:05:21.315 --> 00:05:25.295
And things like that, so there's four

93
00:05:26.705 --> 00:05:32.505
deliverables that are associated with
the two exams and two answer sheets.

94
00:05:32.505 --> 00:05:36.465
And then there is another download
that will give you instructions for

95
00:05:36.465 --> 00:05:40.495
how you can redeem those discounts for all
those resources including the courseware.

96
00:05:40.495 --> 00:05:41.195
All right.
>> All right.

97
00:05:41.195 --> 00:05:43.570
Well, Terry, thanks so much for
explaining this to us.

98
00:05:43.570 --> 00:05:46.793
And if it sounds like something
that might be interesting to you,

99
00:05:46.793 --> 00:05:49.790
well we look forward to seeing
you in the upcoming episodes.

100
00:05:49.790 --> 00:05:56.140
[SOUND]

episodes.description: ** Download the Episode Files for the information referenced in this course ** In this episode, Daniel and Terry begin their foray into the wonderful world of ITIL Foundation. Here they give you an overview of the topics discussed in the ITIL framework, define ITIL as an entity, and start their discussion of the ITIL Service Lifecycle. They also introduce you to the first of many key concepts and definitions used by ITIL Foundation.
episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Foundation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.110 --> 00:00:14.138
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3
00:00:14.138 --> 00:00:16.474
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.474 --> 00:00:18.075
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,

5
00:00:18.075 --> 00:00:21.860
and in today's episode we begin
our series on ITIL Foundation.

6
00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:26.315
And joining us in the studio to lend his
expertise on that topic is our friend and

7
00:00:26.315 --> 00:00:29.900
[LAUGH] well, our colleague as well,
our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

8
00:00:29.900 --> 00:00:32.120
Terry, welcome to the show,
sir, we're so glad to have you.

9
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:32.840
How are you doing today?

10
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:36.040
>> I'm doing great, Daniel, glad to
be here and we got a lot to learn so

11
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:36.800
let's get started.

12
00:00:38.566 --> 00:00:41.049
As Daniel said, we're here for
ITIL Foundation.

13
00:00:41.049 --> 00:00:43.885
This first episode is on
the introduction topics and

14
00:00:43.885 --> 00:00:47.165
we're basically gonna try
to prepare you for an exam.

15
00:00:47.165 --> 00:00:51.216
That's our primary objective over all of
these episodes is to get you ready to take

16
00:00:51.216 --> 00:00:52.516
the Foundation's exam.

17
00:00:52.516 --> 00:00:57.035
The advantage of taking it through ITProTV
is that the fire hose that I am going to

18
00:00:57.035 --> 00:01:01.083
be throwing out here and you're
drinking from is controlled by you, so

19
00:01:01.083 --> 00:01:04.020
you kind of take it in
the doses that you need.

20
00:01:04.020 --> 00:01:06.020
But there is lots to learn, and again,

21
00:01:06.020 --> 00:01:08.290
we're just setting the table
here with the introduction.

22
00:01:08.290 --> 00:01:11.130
We're going to talk about
the overall framework of ITIL,

23
00:01:11.130 --> 00:01:14.770
the topics are broad and
detailed at the same time.

24
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:19.450
A lot of vocabulary,
a lot of words to learn and let's dive in.

25
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:26.550
Multiple episodes, as I mentioned, and
there'll be up to 13 episodes on and off

26
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:32.870
for the ITIL Foundations, including some
post episode quizzes and some self study.

27
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:36.540
Some of this you need to
do a little homework and

28
00:01:36.540 --> 00:01:39.940
then come to the episodes that's
related to the practice exams.

29
00:01:39.940 --> 00:01:43.830
There's two practice exams associated
with this learning and that's

30
00:01:43.830 --> 00:01:47.460
really where you're going to reinforce
all the things I've been teaching.

31
00:01:49.640 --> 00:01:54.450
This course is officially based on
the five core publications of ITIL.

32
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:58.170
As you can see them listed here,
strategy, design,

33
00:01:58.170 --> 00:02:02.430
transition, operations and
continual service improvement.

34
00:02:02.430 --> 00:02:06.610
These five core books are the books
from which all of the exam

35
00:02:06.610 --> 00:02:07.700
questions are coming from.

36
00:02:08.710 --> 00:02:09.510
The advantage of,

37
00:02:09.510 --> 00:02:12.060
of course, taking a course is,
you don't have to read all five books.

38
00:02:12.060 --> 00:02:16.370
You can learn from me and
take it from there.

39
00:02:16.370 --> 00:02:17.460
>> I prefer that method.

40
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:18.301
>> It's much better.
>> [LAUGH]

41
00:02:18.301 --> 00:02:19.631
>> I wonder, Daniel,

42
00:02:19.631 --> 00:02:25.580
can you see from any commonality among
these graphics that these pictures have?

43
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:28.726
>> There seem to be some sort
of star type pattern to them.

44
00:02:28.726 --> 00:02:29.911
>> Yeah.

45
00:02:29.911 --> 00:02:30.869
>> [CROSSTALK] branching
out with the graphic.

46
00:02:30.869 --> 00:02:34.117
>> Yeah, some of them are definitely
have the star based piece to them,

47
00:02:34.117 --> 00:02:37.201
except the ones kind of look like
peas in the service transition.

48
00:02:37.201 --> 00:02:38.200
>> Like blood in a vessel.

49
00:02:38.200 --> 00:02:39.530
>> Yeah, exactly.

50
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:41.650
What they all are is organic.

51
00:02:41.650 --> 00:02:46.090
They're all organic symbols, and that's
the nature of the ITIL beast, if you will,

52
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:48.210
is that it does grow
within the organization.

53
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:49.655
It's a cultural thing, almost.

54
00:02:49.655 --> 00:02:54.790
So it's a framework that kind of
guides the way to deliver IT services.

55
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:59.160
It is meant to grow and you to grow with
it, so that's kinda the little trivia.

56
00:02:59.160 --> 00:03:03.810
That's not on the exam, don't worry about
that, but just a note about the graphics.

57
00:03:05.620 --> 00:03:09.050
What ITIL stands for,
this is a tough thing.

58
00:03:09.050 --> 00:03:12.161
When I talk to someone on the street
about what do you do, and

59
00:03:12.161 --> 00:03:14.790
I say I teach ITIL courses,
and say what's ITIL?

60
00:03:14.790 --> 00:03:18.806
And I say, well, it's IT infrastructure
library, said, you're a librarian.

61
00:03:18.806 --> 00:03:21.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> I said yep, yep, not really.

62
00:03:22.530 --> 00:03:24.940
So while the name is not
necessarily that descriptive,

63
00:03:24.940 --> 00:03:29.570
it is IT service management framework and
ITIL is the official brand.

64
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:33.002
And once upon a time,
the answer to the question, what is ITIL?

65
00:03:33.002 --> 00:03:37.680
Well, it's simply a set of books and
truly it is, it's a set of books.

66
00:03:37.680 --> 00:03:40.330
It provides guidance, advice, and again,

67
00:03:40.330 --> 00:03:44.290
establishes a solid framework that
prescribes certain things to do.

68
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:48.250
I should say, not prescribe,
it defines certain things

69
00:03:48.250 --> 00:03:50.930
that can make you successful,
but doesn't prescribe them.

70
00:03:50.930 --> 00:03:52.650
You don't have to do them.

71
00:03:52.650 --> 00:03:59.508
Adopt and adapt are the two
words associated with ITIL.

72
00:03:59.508 --> 00:04:02.750
A little bit of history of it,
it's owned now by AXELOS.

73
00:04:02.750 --> 00:04:07.750
It was formed actually out of the Office
of Government Commerce in the UK,

74
00:04:07.750 --> 00:04:12.710
so imagine the US Chamber of
Commerce trying to help businesses.

75
00:04:12.710 --> 00:04:17.200
Well, the Office of Government Commerce,
again in the UK,

76
00:04:17.200 --> 00:04:21.526
ventured out to define what's
the best way to deliver IT.

77
00:04:21.526 --> 00:04:23.560
And they own that venture.

78
00:04:23.560 --> 00:04:29.935
They invited industry experts, academics,
and various folks from the industry and

79
00:04:29.935 --> 00:04:35.791
came up and started writing books, and
said, this is a good way to deliver IT.

80
00:04:35.791 --> 00:04:40.790
And here's what common
best practices look like.

81
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:44.805
And eventually,
it did become a best practice over time.

82
00:04:44.805 --> 00:04:47.340
You'll see some of the milestones here.

83
00:04:47.340 --> 00:04:48.730
Version 3 came out in 2007.

84
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:53.550
They did an update to that version
in 2011, but promised that they

85
00:04:53.550 --> 00:04:58.650
wouldn't reversion ITIL as it went on so
you didn't have to recertify.

86
00:04:58.650 --> 00:04:59.420
>> That is awesome.

87
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:00.498
>> Yeah,
cuz you know some of those [CROSSTALK]

88
00:05:00.498 --> 00:05:01.035
>> Again.

89
00:05:01.035 --> 00:05:02.570
>> Yeah.
>> I've done the IT certifications

90
00:05:02.570 --> 00:05:05.650
throughout my life, and they love to
expire them, and now there's new ones.

91
00:05:05.650 --> 00:05:08.240
The information really
hasn't changed a whole lot,

92
00:05:08.240 --> 00:05:11.860
and now you've got to pay another $400 or
whatever for an exam.

93
00:05:11.860 --> 00:05:12.830
>> Yeah, exactly.

94
00:05:12.830 --> 00:05:17.920
So they promised not to reversion in that
regard, but they do continue to update it.

95
00:05:17.920 --> 00:05:19.030
So there's some information.

96
00:05:19.030 --> 00:05:24.840
They added some four processes to
2011 that kind of broadened it out.

97
00:05:24.840 --> 00:05:28.340
So it's not a dead book, it is organic,
this set of books, they're not dead.

98
00:05:28.340 --> 00:05:30.285
They continue to grow and adapt and

99
00:05:30.285 --> 00:05:34.848
in fact they just launched a new course
back in March called Agile Practitioner,

100
00:05:34.848 --> 00:05:39.294
so that's actually adding to the
curriculum as well and certification pass.

101
00:05:39.294 --> 00:05:42.760
>> Okay.

102
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:44.260
>> This is a busy graphic.

103
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:50.030
It can help test takers focus on a few
things that might show up on an exam.

104
00:05:50.030 --> 00:05:53.410
It's really describing how a best
practice comes into existence.

105
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:56.280
Let me try and make some sense out
of these, I'll get my pointer here.

106
00:05:59.330 --> 00:06:04.030
To show out if you look on the side
over here we have sources and

107
00:06:04.030 --> 00:06:06.860

577
00:31:26.970 --> 00:31:32.860
We had CFOs, we had CIOs, and they said,
yeah, we need this type of claim system.

578
00:31:32.860 --> 00:31:34.998
We bought this electronic claim system.

579
00:31:34.998 --> 00:31:38.510
They never used the thing, but our claims
department, they use it all the time.

580
00:31:38.510 --> 00:31:39.220
>> Exactly.

581
00:31:39.220 --> 00:31:41.340
Someone sponsored it and paid for

582
00:31:41.340 --> 00:31:44.430
it, that's the customer
who actually paid for it.

583
00:31:44.430 --> 00:31:46.040
Then the users are the people
who get it done.

584
00:31:46.040 --> 00:31:48.109
>> Makes sense.

585
00:31:49.640 --> 00:31:52.730
>> That will do it for this episode.

586
00:31:54.490 --> 00:31:56.100
We'll pick back up on the next one.

587
00:31:56.100 --> 00:32:00.210
>> Excellent, we really enjoyed
our introduction into ITIL.

588
00:32:00.210 --> 00:32:03.990
What it is, what we can expect when
it comes to our exam a little bit.

589
00:32:03.990 --> 00:32:08.540
What we can expect with what we are going
to need to know, some key definitions and

590
00:32:08.540 --> 00:32:09.360
things of that nature.

591
00:32:09.360 --> 00:32:13.050
We appreciate that Terry, for
you explaining these things to us.

592
00:32:13.050 --> 00:32:16.140
But like you said, it looks like we have
come down to the end of this episode.

593
00:32:16.140 --> 00:32:17.750
We thank you guys for joining us.

594
00:32:17.750 --> 00:32:18.910
Hopefully, you have learned something.

595
00:32:18.910 --> 00:32:20.890
We look forward to seeing
you in the next one as well.

596
00:32:20.890 --> 00:32:24.950
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

597
00:32:24.950 --> 00:32:26.670
I'm Terry Decker, see you next time.

598
00:32:28.420 --> 00:32:32.642
>> We'll see you next time.

599
00:32:32.642 --> 00:32:35.360
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry continue their introduction into ITIL Foundation; picking back up with more key concepts and definitions. This includes the Process Model, RACI, Process Owner, Manager, Practitioner, and Service Owner.
episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Foundation Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.861 --> 00:00:13.080
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.080 --> 00:00:17.230
Welcome to another great episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:17.230 --> 00:00:21.640
in today's episode we continue on with
starting our series on ITIL Foundation.

5
00:00:21.640 --> 00:00:22.770
Joining us back in the studio for

6
00:00:22.770 --> 00:00:26.600
our part II on the introduction is
our good friend Mr. Terry Decker.

7
00:00:26.600 --> 00:00:28.480
Terry, welcome back sir,
it's so good to have you.

8
00:00:28.480 --> 00:00:30.030
>> Thanks Daniel, glad to be here.

9
00:00:30.030 --> 00:00:31.660
And let's dig right in.

10
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:36.650
You'll recall from the first
section that we discussed

11
00:00:36.650 --> 00:00:40.820
types of IT service providers,
we had internal, shared, and external.

12
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:45.480
So we're gonna begin today
with types of IT services,

13
00:00:45.480 --> 00:00:47.270
as opposed to IT service providers.

14
00:00:48.610 --> 00:00:52.290
Supporting services,
internal customer facing services, or

15
00:00:52.290 --> 00:00:54.710
external customer facing services.

16
00:00:54.710 --> 00:00:57.870
Again, the three types
here of IT services,

17
00:00:57.870 --> 00:01:00.740
as opposed to IT service providers, right.

18
00:01:00.740 --> 00:01:07.390
A supporting service, it is basically,
in the back end if you will,

19
00:01:07.390 --> 00:01:12.990
the back office services, server services,
database services, network services,

20
00:01:12.990 --> 00:01:17.090
the things that allow the front-end
customer facing services to work.

21
00:01:17.090 --> 00:01:20.270
So, an internal customer
facing service could be email.

22
00:01:21.440 --> 00:01:24.160
And underneath that are supporting
services like, servers,

23
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:27.470
databases, networks, right?

24
00:01:27.470 --> 00:01:31.730
And then external customer facing
services are just those services that

25
00:01:31.730 --> 00:01:33.670
are exposed to external customers.

26
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:35.960
Again, probably for
profit but not necessarily.

27
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:37.685
Consider a bank for instance.

28
00:01:37.685 --> 00:01:43.501
A bank has services,
IT services for their employees,

29
00:01:43.501 --> 00:01:49.070
teller software desktops
as you go into the bank.

30
00:01:49.070 --> 00:01:52.100
And then of course we use IT
service as customers in the bank.

31
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:55.770
Even though we don't pay for
those services directly.

32
00:01:55.770 --> 00:01:58.650
We use the ATM machines,
we perhaps use our phone,

33
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:00.590
those IT services to access a bank.

34
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:05.180
So, there's a service provider
that has supporting services,

35
00:02:05.180 --> 00:02:09.610
internal customer facing services and
external customer facing services.

36
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:12.400
So, you could be an IT organization
that is all three of these.

37
00:02:12.400 --> 00:02:16.420
Right, so they're not mutually
exclusive to one organization, right.

38
00:02:16.420 --> 00:02:18.950
And I should add to this that

39
00:02:18.950 --> 00:02:23.130
these are distinctions in some
regards without a difference.

40
00:02:23.130 --> 00:02:26.230
Right, we can distinguish
between a supporting service and

41
00:02:26.230 --> 00:02:29.500
internal customer facing and
an external customer facing service.

42
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:30.831
We can distinguish those.

43
00:02:30.831 --> 00:02:36.600
But as far as ITIL is concerned,
you still need to provide value, right?

44
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:39.820
It's not just because someone is
paying for it that you provide value.

45
00:02:39.820 --> 00:02:42.560
You provide value as a service provider,
right?

46
00:02:42.560 --> 00:02:45.410
So it's important to know these.

47
00:02:45.410 --> 00:02:48.450
But it's also just as important to
understand that these are distinctions,

48
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:54.400
really, without a difference, okay?

49
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:57.520
Another graphical representation of this,
you see external customers,

50
00:02:57.520 --> 00:03:00.550
this is an organization that
has some external customers.

51
00:03:00.550 --> 00:03:05.860
Some of them supporting the business
processes as you can see in this area.

52
00:03:05.860 --> 00:03:10.070
And then other external customers
directly interacting with IT,

53
00:03:10.070 --> 00:03:13.220
without a business process in between.

54
00:03:13.220 --> 00:03:17.400
So imagine a brick and
mortar book seller, right?

55
00:03:17.400 --> 00:03:18.540
That has external customers.

56
00:03:18.540 --> 00:03:20.380
So people walk into the store.

57
00:03:20.380 --> 00:03:24.770
There's IT supporting those points of
sales systems and inventory systems.

58
00:03:24.770 --> 00:03:28.280
And there's business processes that
are affecting inventory management and

59
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:29.290
those types of things.

60
00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:32.170
Right, for that book seller
that's got brick and mortar.

61
00:03:32.170 --> 00:03:35.840
But then you can have external customers
directly interfacing with IT systems and

62
00:03:35.840 --> 00:03:38.890
IT services such as
through their web portal.

63
00:03:38.890 --> 00:03:42.080
They don't go through some middleware,
or I shouldn't say middleware,

64
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:46.570
middleman of business process,
they access the IT services directly.

65
00:03:46.570 --> 00:03:49.833
So, while we do distinguish
between internal,

66
00:03:49.833 --> 00:03:54.297
external, these lines get blurred
quite easily, as you can see.

67
00:03:54.297 --> 00:03:56.650
And again, as far as ITIL is concerned,

68
00:03:56.650 --> 00:04:00.666
you still must bring the same sort
of discipline to providing value,

69
00:04:00.666 --> 00:04:05.590
whether you're internal, external,
or some hybrid of them all.

70
00:04:05.590 --> 00:04:08.960
Okay.

71
00:04:08.960 --> 00:04:13.819
Some other ways to describe
services is core enabling and

72
00:04:13.819 --> 00:04:16.960
enhancing services, right.

73
00:04:16.960 --> 00:04:20.760
Not types of service providers but
types of services.

74
00:04:20.760 --> 00:04:24.730
As an example, email is the service
that most organizations,

75
00:04:24.730 --> 00:04:26.350
most people are familiar with now.

76
00:04:26.350 --> 00:04:27.645
Remember the time before email?

77
00:04:27.645 --> 00:04:30.690
[CROSSTALK]
>> I do remember the time before email.

78
00:04:30.690 --> 00:04:31.300
Yes sir.

79
00:04:31.300 --> 00:04:32.730
>> There was a time before email.

80
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:33.450
>> It did happen.

81
00:04:33.450 --> 00:04:34.190
>> That's right.

82
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:36.090
And there was interoffice memos on paper.

83
00:04:36.090 --> 00:04:39.570
There's a physical inboxes and
outboxes that people used, right?

84
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:44.360
So that core servers providing email,
is something

85
00:04:44.360 --> 00:04:48.659
fairly ubiquitous now,
everyone aware of that core service.

86
00:04:50.480 --> 00:04:55.160
What about email on your phone,
is that also a given?

87
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:56.280
In some organizations, it's not.

88
00:04:56.280 --> 00:04:59.590
You need the mobile email
is not necessarily you get,

89
00:04:59.590 --> 00:05:01.680
that would be called enhancing service.

90
00:05:01.680 --> 00:05:04.690
I know in my experience,
when we first got email,

91
00:05:05.920 --> 00:05:08.610
we didn't necessarily
rule out mobile email.

92
00:05:08.610 --> 00:05:11.720
That was something only the sales
people got for instance, right?

93
00:05:11.720 --> 00:05:15.690
So that was an enhancing service,
and only certain groups got it.

94
00:05:15.690 --> 00:05:21.750
So core is something that's
used by everybody and

95
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:25.520
provides of course services and
enhancing services with those things that

96
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:30.170
maybe a subset of the group of
the customers or the business uses.

97
00:05:30.170 --> 00:05:33.820
An enabling service is akin
to a supporting service.

98
00:05:33.820 --> 00:05:36.430
It's a service that allows
those services to happen.

99
00:05:36.430 --> 00:05:39.120
So what do you need for
email service to work?

100
00:05:40.690 --> 00:05:43.450
>> You need a server,
you need access to a network.

101
00:05:43.450 --> 00:05:44.690
>> So you need identity management,

102
00:05:44.690 --> 00:05:48.420
you need network management,
you need servers, right.

103
00:05:48.420 --> 00:05:52.560
And those types of things in the back are
supporting services, or enabling services.

104
00:05:52.560 --> 00:05:54.080
They let that happen.

105
00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:57.740
Again, in some regards, it's another
distinction without a difference.

106
00:05:57.740 --> 00:06:02.460
You still need to put focus on
delivering value to your customers.

107
00:06:02.460 --> 00:06:05.840
It's just that an enabling
service doesn't necessarily have

108
00:06:05.840 --> 00:06:07.900
the end user customer in mind.

109
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:12.030
Maybe they have the email service
provider in mind as a customer.

110
00:06:12.030 --> 00:06:15.510
But you still must provide
value to your customers.

111
00:06:20.330 --> 00:06:23.480
All right, folks, more definitions.

112
00:06:23.480 --> 00:06:26.430
I think I'll give you a little apology,
perhaps.

113
00:06:26.430 --> 00:06:31.280
A lot of preparing for this foundation
exam is memorization of words.

114
00:06:31.280 --> 00:06:35.380
And where the apology comes from is
that these are sometimes the words

115
00:06:35.380 --> 00:06:37.590
are something we've used for a long time.

116
00:06:37.590 --> 00:06:40.710
And ITIL has given them
very specific meaning.

117
00:06:40.710 --> 00:06:44.650
If you bring your definition
of the word to the exam,

118
00:06:44.650 --> 00:06:47.730
there could an opportunity for
failure, right?

119
00:06:47.730 --> 00:06:50.830
You won't get the question right because
you're bringing your definition and

120
00:06:50.830 --> 00:06:52.360
not the good old ITIL definition.

121
00:06:52.360 --> 00:06:54.860
So pay attention to definitions here,

122
00:06:54.860 --> 00:06:57.700
I don't expect you to
memorize these as I go.

123
00:06:57.700 --> 00:07:02.290
But you do need to focus back on these
definitions as you do your self-study and

124
00:07:02.290 --> 00:07:04.630
prepare for the exam, right.

125
00:07:04.630 --> 00:07:07.610
Again, nothing really magical
about this definition, a process,

126
00:07:07.610 --> 00:07:12.630
a structured set of activities designed
to accomplish a specific objective.

127
00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:18.780
It takes one or more defined inputs,
and turns them into defined outputs.

128
00:07:18.780 --> 00:07:20.250
Right, fairly straightforward.

129
00:07:22.330 --> 00:07:25.570
So digging in a little bit
deeper to what a process has.

130
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:30.895
ITIL further characterizes processes
as having four attributes.

131
00:07:30.895 --> 00:07:35.975
Every process defined by ITIL
has these same four attributes.

132
00:07:37.065 --> 00:07:40.839
It has in response to a specific trigger.

133
00:07:40.839 --> 00:07:42.600
Now something gets it started.

134
00:07:42.600 --> 00:07:44.360
That's the input, right.

135
00:07:44.360 --> 00:07:48.830
It has a specific output, right,
the process has an output.

136
00:07:48.830 --> 00:07:52.580
It has some sort of stakeholder
being me as a customer,

137
00:07:52.580 --> 00:07:56.590
it delivers that output to
a stakeholder or a customer, right.

138
00:07:56.590 --> 00:07:59.480
A customer is just a type of stakeholder,
right?

139
00:07:59.480 --> 00:08:01.325
And it is measurable.

140
00:08:01.325 --> 00:08:07.605
A process needs to be measurable, and the
implication there is that you measure it.

141
00:08:07.605 --> 00:08:10.860
Later on, when we talk about continuous
service improvement, the foundation of

142
00:08:10.860 --> 00:08:15.860
being able to improve services is to
be able to measure what's underneath

143
00:08:15.860 --> 00:08:21.730
that service, and a measurement process
is one of those key aspects of that.

144
00:08:21.730 --> 00:08:25.560
Definitely worth memorizing these four
attributes as you move forwards in your

145
00:08:25.560 --> 00:08:29.770
studies, specific inputs,
specific outputs, or results.

146
00:08:29.770 --> 00:08:34.580
They deliver those outputs to a specific
stakeholder, a customer could be, and

147
00:08:34.580 --> 00:08:38.040
measurable, again, worth memorizing here.

148
00:08:39.270 --> 00:08:43.080
All right, so
let's talk about measurement just a bit.

149
00:08:43.080 --> 00:08:47.670
Perhaps you're familiar with a service
desk or a help desk, and they follow

150
00:08:47.670 --> 00:08:53.710
processes to resolve when incidence occur,
such as I can't find this,

151
00:08:53.710 --> 00:08:58.680
I can't find that, the applications down,
the service desk is that call, and

152
00:08:58.680 --> 00:09:03.050
follows the process to get it back and
get it restored.

153
00:09:03.050 --> 00:09:05.880
How would you measure
that kind of process?

154
00:09:05.880 --> 00:09:10.240
>> I guess you would have to make
really clearly defined definitions for

155
00:09:10.240 --> 00:09:12.820
each phases of the process.

156
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:17.520
And then they would be able to say, okay,
I accomplished this phase of the process,

157
00:09:17.520 --> 00:09:18.750
and be able to check that off.

158
00:09:18.750 --> 00:09:21.261
Right, not only did you accomplish it.

159
00:09:21.261 --> 00:09:22.980
>> Right.
Perhaps the timescales of it.

160
00:09:22.980 --> 00:09:23.773
How quick they did it?

161
00:09:23.773 --> 00:09:26.886
because we expect service desk to
be responsive and quick, right, so

162
00:09:26.886 --> 00:09:28.640
perhaps you measure the time it takes.

163
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:31.179
So, how long were you on hold?

164
00:09:31.179 --> 00:09:33.518
Did you call, and
were you were on hold for three minutes?

165
00:09:33.518 --> 00:09:35.518
That can be something measured, right?

166
00:09:35.518 --> 00:09:39.370
That can be an element of measuring
just how effective your service desk is.

167
00:09:39.370 --> 00:09:43.829
How long did it take them to
respond that they got your concern?

168
00:09:43.829 --> 00:09:45.970
How long did it take them to resolve it,
right.

169
00:09:45.970 --> 00:09:47.570
So you could measure those things.

170
00:09:47.570 --> 00:09:51.080
But so, we're gonna be describing
some 22 processes this week, and

171
00:09:51.080 --> 00:09:53.300
we're not gonna dive deep
into their measurements.

172
00:09:53.300 --> 00:09:57.830
But understand that every process is
intended to be measured, and that

173
00:09:57.830 --> 00:10:01.058
measurement is showing you the quality of
how good that process is actually working.

174
00:10:01.058 --> 00:10:06.970
Okay, all right, a process model,

175
00:10:06.970 --> 00:10:12.540
this word model is used a lot in ITO,
and it effectively just describes

176
00:10:12.540 --> 00:10:19.050
the various parameters of succeeding
given the particular process, right?

177
00:10:19.050 --> 00:10:24.560
And to be able to succeed in your process
model, you must be able to show control.

178
00:10:24.560 --> 00:10:28.005
You must define your processes themselves,
right.

179
00:10:28.005 --> 00:10:29.970
That's the middle tier here.

180
00:10:29.970 --> 00:10:33.340
And you must also enable people
to know how to use that process,

181
00:10:33.340 --> 00:10:35.850
you have to have people, process enablers.

182
00:10:35.850 --> 00:10:39.850
These are the people that actually
get it done, or the tool sets that

183
00:10:39.850 --> 00:10:43.900
help you get those done,
the enables there, could be technology.

184
00:10:43.900 --> 00:10:49.320
So under process control,
you have things like process policy.

185
00:10:50.330 --> 00:10:54.450
You could have a very,
very good process that would really work,

186
00:10:54.450 --> 00:10:57.250
well if people only followed it, right.

187
00:10:57.250 --> 00:10:59.610
So if people aren't following it,
it's obviously not working,

188
00:10:59.610 --> 00:11:03.730
because people are choosing to go off
the reservation and do their own things.

189
00:11:03.730 --> 00:11:08.130
So no matter how good or bad the process
is, if you don't have some sort of policy

190
00:11:08.130 --> 00:11:12.520
on top of it to say, we got to follow
this process, it's not going to happen.

191
00:11:12.520 --> 00:11:13.860
Right, very well.

192
00:11:13.860 --> 00:11:18.680
So understanding process control is
effectively understanding that there

193
00:11:18.680 --> 00:11:22.610
is a hierarchy of why
we need this process,

194
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:27.930
how we're going to control this process,
what it's intended to do, its objectives.

195
00:11:27.930 --> 00:11:30.276
And you're certainly getting
it documented, right?

196
00:11:30.276 --> 00:11:34.541
And then under process itself is
your metrics, your measurements,

197
00:11:34.541 --> 00:11:38.952
how you go about improving it,
how do you go about testing compliance,

198
00:11:38.952 --> 00:11:43.460
our people actually following this,
so you audit them or you go and see.

199
00:11:43.460 --> 00:11:46.250
You go and look and see, if people
are actually following the process.

200
00:11:46.250 --> 00:11:49.694
That's what process is about, okay.

201
00:11:49.694 --> 00:11:55.040
All right, so we have process,
structure set of steps, instructions.

202
00:11:55.040 --> 00:11:58.290
A function is a team or
group of people and

203
00:11:58.290 --> 00:12:03.130
the tools and resources they use to
carry out one or more processes.

204
00:12:03.130 --> 00:12:06.104
So a process is a set of instructions.

205
00:12:06.104 --> 00:12:11.701
A function is a set of people with
special skills and tools, right?

206
00:12:11.701 --> 00:12:16.704
ITIL is really good at distilling
these definitions down, right,

207
00:12:16.704 --> 00:12:21.722
and there's only four functions
described by ITIL, only four..

208
00:12:21.722 --> 00:12:25.884
There's 26 processes,
22 are in scope of foundations, and

209
00:12:25.884 --> 00:12:29.410
there are four functions,
and they show up here.

00:32:08.670 --> 00:32:10.070
It will be super easy.

578
00:32:10.070 --> 00:32:13.827
I didn't know that that router
was gonna cost $50,000 though.

579
00:32:13.827 --> 00:32:15.280
You know, yeah.

580
00:32:15.280 --> 00:32:18.440
So it's probably, like you said,
a good idea to have a plan beforehand,

581
00:32:18.440 --> 00:32:20.880
start thinking of these things beforehand.

582
00:32:20.880 --> 00:32:24.910
As much pre-planning as you can do before
you jump into the deep end of that pool,

583
00:32:24.910 --> 00:32:26.180
it's probably going to help out a lot.

584
00:32:26.180 --> 00:32:28.350
So we look forward to
the next episode as well.

585
00:32:28.350 --> 00:32:30.630
But Terry looks like our time
has expired from this one.

586
00:32:30.630 --> 00:32:33.410
So where gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

587
00:32:33.410 --> 00:32:35.210
I have been you host Daniel Lowrie.

588
00:32:35.210 --> 00:32:35.920
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

589
00:32:35.920 --> 00:32:38.342
>> We'll see you next time.

590
00:32:38.342 --> 00:32:45.321
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry discuss Service Design, the second of five Service Lifecycle stages. Here they begin talking about the objectives and scope of the Service Design stage and then take a close look at 2 of the 8 Service Design processes, Design Coordination and Service Level Management.
episodes.title: Service Design
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.039 --> 00:00:10.039
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.857 --> 00:00:16.200
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.200 --> 00:00:17.320
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:17.320 --> 00:00:19.930
And in today's episode we
are moving forward with more

5
00:00:19.930 --> 00:00:22.180
on our ITIL Foundation series.

6
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:24.322
Joining us back in the studio, you know
who it is, you know him, you love him,

7
00:00:24.322 --> 00:00:25.247
he's number one in your hearts.

8
00:00:25.247 --> 00:00:27.540
Our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

9
00:00:27.540 --> 00:00:29.360
Terry, welcome back, sir, how's it going?

10
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:31.020
>> I'm glad to be back, thanks much.

11
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:34.530
And as you recall,
we've done service strategy.

12
00:00:34.530 --> 00:00:38.480
Now, we're going to dive into the second
of our five life cycle stages,

13
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:39.940
service design.

14
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:43.220
And it's a big one, this one's gonna
be broken up into a couple episodes.

15
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:45.950
If you look on your screen there,
you can see that in fact,

16
00:00:45.950 --> 00:00:49.700
there is eight processes
in service design.

17
00:00:49.700 --> 00:00:53.470
And before we get to those processes,
we're gonna be talking about some of

18
00:00:53.470 --> 00:00:58.800
the high level aspects of design stage at
large and pick up some good vocabulary.

19
00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:00.980
As always we need to learn a few words.

20
00:01:00.980 --> 00:01:02.682
>> They love it,
the ITIL learn their vocab.

21
00:01:02.682 --> 00:01:04.080
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

22
00:01:04.080 --> 00:01:05.050
There will be words.

23
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:06.920
There will be words so
we'll get to some of those as well.

24
00:01:06.920 --> 00:01:08.410
>> And words that describe those words.

25
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:09.400
That'll be fun.

26
00:01:09.400 --> 00:01:12.400
>> Exactly.
[LAUGH] That's right.

27
00:01:12.400 --> 00:01:16.590
And again the purpose of service design, a
little bit of tongue in cheek here, is to

28
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:22.310
design services effectively and to make
sure you're satisfying service strategy.

29
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:26.750
But I want to focus
a little bit on service as

30
00:01:26.750 --> 00:01:31.470
opposed to solutions design or
systems design or architectural design.

31
00:01:31.470 --> 00:01:34.313
I want to focus on service design just for
a little bit.

32
00:01:34.313 --> 00:01:39.540
And to just basically highlight a story
from a few years ago, early 2000s.

33
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.780
I wasn't at the meeting, but I can imagine
this meeting of the IT infrastructure

34
00:01:43.780 --> 00:01:47.040
folks, they're in a meeting and someone
suggested that there's been a lot of

35
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:52.600
people talking about the need for
having work team FileShares.

36
00:01:52.600 --> 00:01:54.370
You had your personal FileShares but

37
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:57.860
work teams need their FileShares
tooAnd the premise being,

38
00:01:57.860 --> 00:02:02.670
a team leader could gain a FileShare and
then be able to administer as he wish.

39
00:02:02.670 --> 00:02:04.800
Passes out permissions as he wants to.

40
00:02:04.800 --> 00:02:05.930
It's a good idea.

41
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:08.430
And Jimmy was a server FileShare guy,
he was in the room.

42
00:02:08.430 --> 00:02:09.860
He says yeah, we can do that.

43
00:02:09.860 --> 00:02:12.450
I'll get some more storage for us.

44
00:02:12.450 --> 00:02:13.790
I'll allocate it.

45
00:02:13.790 --> 00:02:16.610
And let's just make it happen, right?

46
00:02:16.610 --> 00:02:20.160
So I'm not sure how the meeting
adjourned but Jimmy was the man,

47
00:02:20.160 --> 00:02:21.910
he was gonna get this done.

48
00:02:21.910 --> 00:02:23.410
I was a work team leader.

49
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:28.130
I happened to be the technical operations
manager for a learning management system.

50
00:02:28.130 --> 00:02:31.370
And I needed FileShare,
exactly what of need I had.

51
00:02:31.370 --> 00:02:34.190
And here was the infrastructure
team gonna supply that need.

52
00:02:34.190 --> 00:02:38.160
So I called Jimmy, because I heard
about it on the elevator sometime or

53
00:02:38.160 --> 00:02:40.440
at a water cooler, and Jimmy was the man.

54
00:02:40.440 --> 00:02:43.460
So I give Jimmy a call and
say, I need some FileShares.

55
00:02:43.460 --> 00:02:45.970
I need five gigs worth of space.

56
00:02:45.970 --> 00:02:47.550
He said, I'm sorry,
you can only have 1 gig.

57
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:49.150
I said, what do you mean only one gig?

58
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:50.440
I need five gigs.

59
00:02:50.440 --> 00:02:53.310
I said, well can I have five one gigs?

60
00:02:53.310 --> 00:02:54.740
And Jimmy said, okay, yeah.

61
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:56.320
You can have five one gig FileShares.

62
00:02:56.320 --> 00:02:56.960
So, all right.

63
00:02:56.960 --> 00:02:58.860
I've got my five, one gig FileShares.

64
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:03.350
And I was storing things for
my work team like XML files,

65
00:03:03.350 --> 00:03:06.550
jar files, just various things to
develop this learning management system.

66
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:11.800
And pictures here and
graphics there, all kinds of stuff.

67
00:03:11.800 --> 00:03:15.730
One Saturday morning I come in with
my work team, 8:00 in the morning,

68
00:03:15.730 --> 00:03:17.790
we're gonna be rolling out this
learning management system.

69
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:19.198
It's going live on Monday.

70
00:03:19.198 --> 00:03:24.330
I come in on Saturday and
the FileShares aren't there.

71
00:03:24.330 --> 00:03:25.940
And Jimmy's nowhere to be found, right.

72
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:27.625
I don't know what I'm gonna do.

73
00:03:27.625 --> 00:03:30.960
1:00 in the afternoon,
I still haven't got the work, right.

74
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:34.560
And Jimmy happens to get back to me and
Says, yeah, what are you doing, Terry?

75
00:03:34.560 --> 00:03:38.280
I said, well I'm trying to build out my
learning management system this week and

76
00:03:38.280 --> 00:03:39.150
the FileShares aren't ready.

77
00:03:39.150 --> 00:03:40.590
He says, well of course they're not ready.

78
00:03:40.590 --> 00:03:42.070
We maintain the servers on the weekend.

79
00:03:42.070 --> 00:03:43.650
That's when we do maintenance.

80
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:45.090
They were probably being patched or
something.

81
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:46.260
I don't know what was going on.

82
00:03:46.260 --> 00:03:47.420
But that's why they're not available.

83
00:03:47.420 --> 00:03:48.730
They're not supposed to be
available on the weekend.

84
00:03:48.730 --> 00:03:50.850
I said, we didn't tell me that.

85
00:03:50.850 --> 00:03:51.890
I didn't know.

86
00:03:51.890 --> 00:03:53.780
And he said, and spy what are you doing?

87
00:03:53.780 --> 00:03:56.720
I said, well I'm storing these
artifacts that I need for developing.

88
00:03:56.720 --> 00:03:58.820
He said, you're not suppose
to store that stuff there.

89
00:03:59.820 --> 00:04:02.520
So there I was,
five hours late to my project.

90
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:05.020
I got it done, I got launched on time.

91
00:04:05.020 --> 00:04:07.870
But I did understand even without given

92
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:12.380
words that there was a difference between
a service and a solution on that very day.

93
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:15.020
Is that I didn't know
the rules of engagement fully.

94
00:04:15.020 --> 00:04:20.030
I didn't know that I was not supposed to
keep my source code like things in there.

95
00:04:20.030 --> 00:04:22.730
I didn't know that it wasn't going
to be available on a Saturday.

96
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:24.000
No one told me, right?

97
00:04:24.000 --> 00:04:24.740
That sort of thing.

98
00:04:24.740 --> 00:04:29.025
So when you're designing a service,
you can't simply design a solution and

99
00:04:29.025 --> 00:04:30.895
prop it up, right.

100
00:04:30.895 --> 00:04:34.335
It has to have these other things
around like governance, like process,

101
00:04:34.335 --> 00:04:37.425
like communications,
like change control communications,

102
00:04:37.425 --> 00:04:39.940
like who to call when it's not available.

103
00:04:39.940 --> 00:04:41.070
Those types of things.

104
00:04:41.070 --> 00:04:43.140
Cuz I called the service desk,
they had no clue.

105
00:04:43.140 --> 00:04:44.980
This was Jimmy's idea, right.

106
00:04:44.980 --> 00:04:46.840
It wasn't that the service
desk didn't support it.

107
00:04:46.840 --> 00:04:50.870
It was kind of IT for IT so
they didn't think they needed to care.

108
00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:53.205
Well, ITIL has a different
approach to that.

109
00:04:53.205 --> 00:04:55.310
ITIL suggests you care, right.

110
00:04:55.310 --> 00:04:59.370
And to understand who's using
these solutions as a service,

111
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:02.730
not just something you prop and
hopes works.

112
00:05:02.730 --> 00:05:08.810
So when you consider service design,
you must consider a lot broader sphere

113
00:05:08.810 --> 00:05:13.750
of controls and processes and
mechanisms that make it work.

114
00:05:13.750 --> 00:05:15.620
It's not simply propping up a solution.

115
00:05:16.990 --> 00:05:20.750
So you're answering lots of questions
when you do a service design.

116
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:25.480
So the scope of service design is

117
00:05:27.190 --> 00:05:32.550
broadly, just making sure you deliver
the right processes, the right procedures,

118
00:05:32.550 --> 00:05:36.350
the right solutions are part of it,
systems are part of it.

119
00:05:36.350 --> 00:05:38.630
So, it's not that those
things aren't valuable.

120
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:41.088
It's just they aren't the only thing.

121
00:05:41.088 --> 00:05:42.910
>> Right, all right.

122
00:05:45.128 --> 00:05:49.230
>> Service design is intended to deliver
on lots of different business values.

123
00:05:49.230 --> 00:05:52.710
Certainly on reducing total cost of
ownership by being good at this, right?

124
00:05:52.710 --> 00:05:56.290
You don't need to reinvent the wheel
every time you need to design a service.

125
00:05:56.290 --> 00:06:00.510
You have repeatable processes that work,
so you can do that effectively.

126
00:06:00.510 --> 00:06:02.990
You can respond to business needs quickly,

127
00:06:02.990 --> 00:06:05.894
if you're really gonna therefore reduce
the total cost of ownership as well.

128
00:06:05.894 --> 00:06:14.130
All right, the four Ps,
definitely worth memorizing.

129
00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:15.240
Test takers.

130
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:17.640
The four Ps of service design.

131
00:06:18.650 --> 00:06:22.380
The way I remember it is two are related
to people and two have prose.

132
00:06:22.380 --> 00:06:25.130
People and partners are the people ones.

133
00:06:25.130 --> 00:06:29.400
Processes and
products are the pros, if you will.

134
00:06:29.400 --> 00:06:32.170
Two people and two pros.

135
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:34.760
Again, not just thinking
about solutions here.

136
00:06:34.760 --> 00:06:37.880
In fact only one of these
Ps deals with the solution.

137
00:06:37.880 --> 00:06:41.220
That's the product side,
that's where the technology is.

138
00:06:41.220 --> 00:06:45.320
IT delivers technical solutions or
products, sure they do.

139
00:06:45.320 --> 00:06:48.290
So that's really the only aspect here

140
00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:52.360
that's related to just the technology
stuff, just the solution side.

141
00:06:52.360 --> 00:06:55.930
The rest of them are related to
the things that make it a service.

142
00:06:55.930 --> 00:06:57.770
What processes are in place?

143
00:06:57.770 --> 00:06:59.350
What people need to be trained?

144
00:06:59.350 --> 00:07:00.990
What people are involved,

145
00:07:00.990 --> 00:07:05.220
on the business side, as well as on
the service provider side, right?

146
00:07:05.220 --> 00:07:09.170
And of course, we don't deliver anything
in IT these days without having some sort

147
00:07:09.170 --> 00:07:10.330
of supplier involved.

148
00:07:10.330 --> 00:07:14.610
Whether it be for software or for
servers or for printer cartridges or

149
00:07:14.610 --> 00:07:20.320
whatever our partners,
our suppliers or third party partners

150
00:07:20.320 --> 00:07:23.530
are gonna be part of the solution as well,
to make sure they're properly engaged.

151
00:07:23.530 --> 00:07:26.640
And again, I wanna ask you to keep in mind

152
00:07:27.840 --> 00:07:33.530
the value of this happening early
in the life cycle of a service.

153
00:07:33.530 --> 00:07:34.970
You don't think of these things later,

154
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:38.460
after you've launched the service,
because you're gonna stumble.

155
00:07:38.460 --> 00:07:39.820
You think of them early.

156
00:07:39.820 --> 00:07:43.410
So that's why these considerations
are early in the life cycle of the service

157
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:44.860
in service design.

158
00:07:44.860 --> 00:07:45.360
Okay.

159
00:07:47.130 --> 00:07:52.110
Another way to consider
the aspects of service design is

160
00:07:52.110 --> 00:07:53.590
these five major aspects here.

161
00:07:53.590 --> 00:07:56.220
You've go the four P's and
here's some other ones.

162
00:07:56.220 --> 00:07:57.590
And some of them are redundant, for

163
00:07:57.590 --> 00:08:00.490
instance under processes,
number five here.

164
00:08:00.490 --> 00:08:02.784
Processes is one of the Ps, right.

165
00:08:02.784 --> 00:08:04.860
Service Solutions, number one here.

166
00:08:04.860 --> 00:08:08.257
Service Solutions is really kind of
related to the To the products side of

167
00:08:08.257 --> 00:08:09.211
things over there.

168
00:08:09.211 --> 00:08:11.211
Right?
So some of these are overlap.

169
00:08:11.211 --> 00:08:15.500
But here's the five major
aspects of service design.

170
00:08:15.500 --> 00:08:18.690
Understanding your own
tool sets within IT.

171
00:08:18.690 --> 00:08:21.380
So your management information systems and
tools.

172
00:08:21.380 --> 00:08:23.460
How are you gonna manage this service?

173
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:26.610
Consider Jimmy and
the file shares situation.

174
00:08:26.610 --> 00:08:29.292
He gave me five 1 Gig file shares.

175
00:08:29.292 --> 00:08:35.420
He needsto be able to know if I'm running
out of space, for instance, or If I'm

176
00:08:35.420 --> 00:08:39.750
not managing administration, security
wise, too many people have access,

177
00:08:39.750 --> 00:08:43.720
maybe I grant seven people administrative
access to them when I shouldn't have.

178
00:08:43.720 --> 00:08:48.960
So being able to look at
that particular service and

179
00:08:48.960 --> 00:08:51.310
manage it is what management
information systems is about.

180
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:54.740
And, of course your technology and
management architectures.

181
00:08:55.750 --> 00:08:56.850
Is it a web server?

182
00:08:56.850 --> 00:08:58.650
Is it client server?

183
00:08:58.650 --> 00:09:00.380
Is it web based?

184
00:09:00.380 --> 00:09:04.100
Those kinds of architectures are in place,
as well as the management architectures.

185
00:09:04.100 --> 00:09:08.120
Who Is responsible for
approving these changes here, and

186
00:09:08.120 --> 00:09:12.490
who is responsible for implementing these
changes there, those sort of things.

187
00:09:12.490 --> 00:09:16.440
And then coming up with
effective means of measurements.

188
00:09:16.440 --> 00:09:19.720
Measurements, methods, and metrics.

189
00:09:19.720 --> 00:09:21.120
If you and your service or

190
00:09:21.120 --> 00:09:25.850
the business have promised that you
could deliver a hundred changes a month.

191
00:09:25.850 --> 00:09:28.860
Do you have the ability
to actually monitor

192
00:09:28.860 --> 00:09:31.200
the volume of changes that
service is gonna have?

193
00:09:31.200 --> 00:09:33.590
Can you keep score, right?

194
00:09:33.590 --> 00:09:37.660
If you're promising a very
highly responsive service desk,

195
00:09:37.660 --> 00:09:40.210
are you measuring the responsiveness
of the service desk?

196
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:45.810
So, if you're gonna promise something then
you need to be able to measure it and

197
00:09:45.810 --> 00:09:51.300
service design is where you ensure you
have those methods of measurement in play.

198
00:09:51.300 --> 00:09:51.800
Okay.

199
00:09:53.000 --> 00:09:57.560
And these next several slides
are related to those things.

200
00:09:57.560 --> 00:09:58.890
Okay.

201
00:09:58.890 --> 00:10:03.532
The Service Design package this is big.

202
00:10:03.532 --> 00:10:09.410
When you're designing a service,

203
00:10:09.410 --> 00:10:16.470
and you're considering those four P's,
people, partners, processes and products.

204
00:10:16.470 --> 00:10:21.050
When you consider those four P's, there's
lots of t's to cross and i's to dot.

205
00:10:21.050 --> 00:10:23.670
There's lots of things
you have to get together.

206
00:10:23.670 --> 00:10:25.530
Think about just on the solutions side.

207
00:10:25.530 --> 00:10:28.340
On the solutions side you're
gonna need business requirements,

208
00:10:28.340 --> 00:10:33.480
system requirements, maybe a design
specification an architectural diagram,

209
00:10:33.480 --> 00:10:37.520
pictures of the way
the solution is designed.

210
00:10:37.520 --> 00:10:41.510
Perhaps you're going to need to define
some processes like change management

211
00:10:41.510 --> 00:10:46.080
processes, instrument management processes
or what requests are gonna be allowed.

212
00:10:46.080 --> 00:10:47.196
I need a new headset.

213
00:10:47.196 --> 00:10:48.450
I need a new server.

214
00:10:48.450 --> 00:10:49.990
I need a new file share.

215
00:10:49.990 --> 00:10:53.610
How are you going to engage the business
on those kinds of requests right?

216
00:10:53.610 --> 00:10:56.830
So lots of things to ask and
have an answer to.

217
00:10:57.850 --> 00:11:02.782
The service design package is really
the answer to all those questions right?

218
00:11:02.782 --> 00:11:05.030
They usually come in
the form of documents.

219
00:11:05.030 --> 00:11:07.340
So the name package is a good name.

220
00:11:07.340 --> 00:11:09.680
And then there's probably
a stack of things.

221
00:11:09.680 --> 00:11:12.530
It's the business requirements document
followed by the service requirements

222
00:11:12.530 --> 00:11:15.040
documents, the design specs,
architectural diagram.
