463
00:23:27.610 --> 00:23:30.680
it does matter what ITIL thinks,
if you wanna pass the exam.

464
00:23:30.680 --> 00:23:34.940
And SLA is an agreement that
has targets inside it, so

465
00:23:34.940 --> 00:23:37.620
let's keep those concepts straight there.

466
00:23:39.370 --> 00:23:44.100
Now a service level agreement, is a very
specific type of agreement in ITIL.

467
00:23:44.100 --> 00:23:46.890
It's the agreement between
the service provider and

468
00:23:46.890 --> 00:23:52.660
the IT customer and it's negotiated
by the service level manager.

469
00:23:52.660 --> 00:23:54.950
The service level management process.

470
00:23:54.950 --> 00:24:00.470
So an Operational Level Agreement is an
agreement between the service provider and

471
00:24:00.470 --> 00:24:04.160
a sibling provider within
the same organization.

472
00:24:04.160 --> 00:24:09.780
So, as example, again, first a SLA between
the service provider and the customers.

473
00:24:09.780 --> 00:24:13.890
So let say I'm the messaging
service provider email.

474
00:24:13.890 --> 00:24:16.417
I have an agreement
with the customers that

475
00:24:16.417 --> 00:24:20.568
email will be available 24/7 except for
maintenance on Sundays.

476
00:24:20.568 --> 00:24:24.555
The service desk will be
responsive within two minutes, and

477
00:24:24.555 --> 00:24:27.340
they'll resolve within two days.

478
00:24:27.340 --> 00:24:28.068
Something like that.

479
00:24:28.068 --> 00:24:31.540
So I got those targets, and I agree
to those targets with the customer.

480
00:24:31.540 --> 00:24:34.655
SLA would have that agreement, right?

481
00:24:34.655 --> 00:24:39.103
I then turn to my server team and
have an OLA with them that says, hey,

482
00:24:39.103 --> 00:24:44.640
these servers need to be available 24/7
except for maintenance on Sundays.

483
00:24:44.640 --> 00:24:48.771
So I have an operational level agreement
with the sibling part of my service

484
00:24:48.771 --> 00:24:52.837
provider that says, I need you to
deliver services 24/7, except for

485
00:24:52.837 --> 00:24:54.233
maintenance on Sunday.

486
00:24:54.233 --> 00:24:58.640
So do not think about maintaining
those servers on Saturday.

487
00:24:58.640 --> 00:24:59.390
Right, that kind of thing.

488
00:24:59.390 --> 00:25:01.890
So I have a separate agreement with them,
all right?

489
00:25:01.890 --> 00:25:07.288
So an SLA, agreement between
the service provider and the customer.

490
00:25:07.288 --> 00:25:12.272
And OLA is an agreement between
the service provider and

491
00:25:12.272 --> 00:25:17.795
a supporting service within
the same organization, right?

492
00:25:17.795 --> 00:25:22.712
Now, an underpinning contract is an
agreement between the service provider and

493
00:25:22.712 --> 00:25:27.789
some third party outside the organization
that helps them to deliver the service.

494
00:25:28.900 --> 00:25:32.870
Now, underpinning contracts are not
managed by service level management.

495
00:25:32.870 --> 00:25:36.300
They're listed here because they're
one of the types of agreements, right?

496
00:25:36.300 --> 00:25:39.190
But it just so happens that
underpinning contracts are managed by

497
00:25:39.190 --> 00:25:42.220
supplier management,
not by service level management.

498
00:25:42.220 --> 00:25:45.490
And we're gonna talk about
supplier management next, okay?

499
00:25:45.490 --> 00:25:46.650
Again, good fodder for

500
00:25:46.650 --> 00:25:51.090
a test exam question here on all
these types of agreements, okay.

501
00:25:52.970 --> 00:25:56.976
Now, how to set up your SLAs in
terms of the overall framework.

502
00:25:56.976 --> 00:25:59.294
And there's several methods
here that could be, and

503
00:25:59.294 --> 00:26:02.400
they're not mutually exclusive,
you could have some sort of hybrid.

504
00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:06.110
That's what the multilevels about,
you see at the bottom there.

505
00:26:06.110 --> 00:26:08.850
So there's effectively three
types of structures, if you will.

506
00:26:08.850 --> 00:26:13.340
The service-based SLA would be,
such as email.

507
00:26:13.340 --> 00:26:17.301
Here's my service,
here's the agreed levels of service,

508
00:26:17.301 --> 00:26:22.370
no matter what the customer is,
no matter who the customer is.

509
00:26:22.370 --> 00:26:25.047
So it's a service-based SLA.

510
00:26:25.047 --> 00:26:29.000
A customer-based SLA would be,
here's the customer and

511
00:26:29.000 --> 00:26:33.044
here's what we've agreed to
with that customer, right.

512
00:26:33.044 --> 00:26:36.119
And maybe there's several services
in that particular agreement and

513
00:26:36.119 --> 00:26:37.169
targets within there.

514
00:26:37.169 --> 00:26:42.087
And then a corporate level SLA
could be an SLA that would be kind

515
00:26:42.087 --> 00:26:45.220
of like a corporate standard, right?

516
00:26:45.220 --> 00:26:49.740
And everyone gets it, regardless of what
customer it is, or what service it is.

517
00:26:49.740 --> 00:26:53.790
Right, so you could have
a customer-based SLA that would

518
00:26:53.790 --> 00:26:57.437
highlight those things
that everyone's gonna do.

519
00:26:57.437 --> 00:27:02.640
And of course, multi-level is some sort
of hybrid approach to all those, okay.

520
00:27:02.640 --> 00:27:05.326
All right, a good old SLAM chart,

521
00:27:05.326 --> 00:27:10.860
otherwise known as service level
agreement monitoring chart.

522
00:27:10.860 --> 00:27:17.750
This is reinforcing the idea that
visual graphics, visual representation

523
00:27:17.750 --> 00:27:22.530
of your measurements can be more
powerful than just numbers and letters.

524
00:27:22.530 --> 00:27:25.910
As an example, in this particular one,
there's, say, period one, two, three and

525
00:27:25.910 --> 00:27:29.110
four is January, February,
March, and April and

526
00:27:29.110 --> 00:27:34.640
target A is incident resolution time, and
target B is incident response time, and

527
00:27:34.640 --> 00:27:40.280
target C is uptime, for instance,
or availability, right?

528
00:27:40.280 --> 00:27:43.391
And then the red, yellow,
and green is red is bad.

529
00:27:43.391 --> 00:27:47.000
You've gone past the LSLA.

530
00:27:47.000 --> 00:27:48.140
Green is good.

531
00:27:48.140 --> 00:27:51.760
And yellow is, you're really
getting close to failure there.

532
00:27:51.760 --> 00:27:54.140
So it can be a quick way
to share information.

533
00:27:55.780 --> 00:27:58.520
As an exam taker,
you're not gonna get a lot on this.

534
00:27:58.520 --> 00:28:01.900
You're not gonna be asked at
the foundation level anyway to

535
00:28:01.900 --> 00:28:04.015
interpret a SLAM chart.

536
00:28:04.015 --> 00:28:08.980
Knowing what a SLAM chart is
the operative thing here, okay.

537
00:28:10.420 --> 00:28:10.920
All right.

538
00:28:13.610 --> 00:28:17.660
These processes, all these processes
can interact with other processes.

539
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:22.120
Service level management has quite a bit
of interaction with these four processes.

540
00:28:22.120 --> 00:28:25.930
Business relationship management,
as I mentioned before, BRM might be

541
00:28:25.930 --> 00:28:29.960
involved in discerning the business
requirements early, at a high level.

542
00:28:29.960 --> 00:28:33.100
And those might morph into
system-level requirements, or,

543
00:28:33.100 --> 00:28:36.350
sorry, service level requirements, right?

544
00:28:36.350 --> 00:28:38.989
So SLM and BRM,
service level management and

545
00:28:38.989 --> 00:28:43.031
business relationship management,
need to be aware of each other.

546
00:28:43.031 --> 00:28:47.805
Another way to look at this is that if
business relationship management is making

547
00:28:47.805 --> 00:28:52.791
sure that customers are getting what they
need and service level management is doing

548
00:28:52.791 --> 00:28:57.285
some measurement that in some regards
approximates those needs being met,

549
00:28:57.285 --> 00:29:01.560
then obviously they're gonna
be related to each other.

550
00:29:01.560 --> 00:29:06.548
Another way to look at that is, I'll just
ask you, is it possible that a service

551
00:29:06.548 --> 00:29:11.535
level manager could come into a meeting
with a customer with all green metrics,

552
00:29:11.535 --> 00:29:16.770
everything looks good, and the customer
still not be satisfied with the service?

553
00:29:16.770 --> 00:29:17.800
Is that possible?

554
00:29:19.170 --> 00:29:23.350
Right, so again, it's kind of a rhetorical
question but yes, it is possible.

555
00:29:23.350 --> 00:29:27.080
So SLM and
BRM need to understand each other and

556
00:29:27.080 --> 00:29:31.506
work together to make a full picture
of just what customers are getting.

557
00:29:31.506 --> 00:29:32.668
All right?

558
00:29:32.668 --> 00:29:38.180
Supplier management is negotiating
those external contracts.

559
00:29:38.180 --> 00:29:41.320
And they also need to be working closely
with the service level management to

560
00:29:41.320 --> 00:29:46.490
make sure that the agreements that
are signed off on with a third party

561
00:29:46.490 --> 00:29:50.450
are actually supporting the agreements
that you're signing off inside.

562
00:29:50.450 --> 00:29:54.514
As an example, it would be silly, for
instance, for you to have an SLA,

563
00:29:54.514 --> 00:29:58.448
a service-level agreement,
negotiated with a customer that says,

564
00:29:58.448 --> 00:30:02.315
I will respond within two days, or
resolve within two days, and then

565
00:30:02.315 --> 00:30:07.072
have an agreement with a supplier that
says, we'll resolve within three, right?

566
00:30:07.072 --> 00:30:08.260
You see how that would be incompatible?

567
00:30:08.260 --> 00:30:11.000
So they need to be on the same page,
service level management,

568
00:30:11.000 --> 00:30:11.870
supplier management.

569
00:30:12.870 --> 00:30:15.900
Of course, service level management
integrates with design coordination,

570
00:30:15.900 --> 00:30:19.030
because design coordination integrates
with the all the processes and

571
00:30:19.030 --> 00:30:20.820
service design.

572
00:30:20.820 --> 00:30:22.080
Incident management.

573
00:30:22.080 --> 00:30:25.170
Certainly, incident management
could be one of the key

574
00:30:25.170 --> 00:30:29.030
processes that will end
up being measured by SLM.

575
00:30:30.390 --> 00:30:32.290
This is not an exhaustive list either.

576
00:30:32.290 --> 00:30:33.840
Anything can be measured.

577
00:30:33.840 --> 00:30:36.630
The customer may have a concern
about change management, so

578
00:30:36.630 --> 00:30:39.060
you could measure change management and
still be in play that way.

579
00:30:40.270 --> 00:30:40.770
All right.

580
00:30:43.000 --> 00:30:45.639
One more process, I'm sorry,
we've got two more processes.

581
00:30:46.800 --> 00:30:49.170
Let's talk about supplier management and
service catalog management.

582
00:30:50.310 --> 00:30:54.800
So, let's leave those for
the next episode, and we'll see you soon.

583
00:30:54.800 --> 00:30:56.382
>> Yeah, well.

584
00:30:56.382 --> 00:30:58.072
Terry, that was really good stuff.

585
00:30:58.072 --> 00:31:02.078
Actually I was interested in how you were
talking about SLAs, because coming from

586
00:31:02.078 --> 00:31:05.691
IT, we think SLAs, I'm thinking
exactly what you're saying, right?

587
00:31:05.691 --> 00:31:09.942
We don't think of it as being more nuanced
than that, as ITIL has broken it down with

588
00:31:09.942 --> 00:31:13.951
the SLTs, which actually makes a whole
lot more sense when you think about it,

589
00:31:13.951 --> 00:31:17.560
because you have the overarching
SLA with the SLTs inside of them.

590
00:31:17.560 --> 00:31:19.140
>> Right.
>> And that's what we wanna reference, so

591
00:31:19.140 --> 00:31:21.880
I think it's a really good job that they
did that, and an excellent job of you of

592
00:31:21.880 --> 00:31:24.290
explaining it to us, so
that we can figure that out, as well.

593
00:31:24.290 --> 00:31:26.420
Looking forward to
seeing that part two and

594
00:31:26.420 --> 00:31:30.270
finishing out this life cycle phase here.

595
00:31:30.270 --> 00:31:34.580
So that being said, I will bid
you good people a fond farewell.

596
00:31:34.580 --> 00:31:37.083
We will be signing off for ITProTV.

597
00:31:37.083 --> 00:31:38.289
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

598
00:31:38.289 --> 00:31:39.962
>> Thanks, Terry Decker.

599
00:31:39.962 --> 00:31:41.393
See you next time.
>> And we'll see you next time.

600
00:31:41.393 --> 00:31:47.053
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry discuss Service Design, the second of five Service Lifecycle stages. They pick back up by finishing their look into the other 6 Service Design Processes which includes Supplier Management, service Catalog Management, Capacity Management, Availability Management, IT Service Continuity Management, and Information Security Management.
episodes.title: Service Design Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.119 --> 00:00:10.119
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.368 --> 00:00:16.500
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:18.560
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.560 --> 00:00:21.990
we are continuing on with
our ITIL Foundation series.

5
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:25.670
Joining us back in the studio again today
is our good friend Mr. Terry Decker.

6
00:00:25.670 --> 00:00:26.902
Terry, welcome back sir.

7
00:00:26.902 --> 00:00:28.136
Good to have you today, how's it going?

8
00:00:28.136 --> 00:00:29.000
>> Good to be here, Daniel.

9
00:00:30.210 --> 00:00:31.100
Ready to get started here.

10
00:00:31.100 --> 00:00:36.430
We finished up our last episode with
half way through service design.

11
00:00:36.430 --> 00:00:40.245
You'll recall that we did design
coordination, service level management.

12
00:00:40.245 --> 00:00:42.020
And you just look at the slide here,

13
00:00:42.020 --> 00:00:44.330
you'll see the kind of context
where we're going today.

14
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:48.100
As I've said, we've done design
coordination, service level management.

15
00:00:48.100 --> 00:00:50.390
And now to supplier management and

16
00:00:50.390 --> 00:00:54.560
as you can see, about five more
processes after that in this episode.

17
00:00:54.560 --> 00:00:55.650
So a lot to learn.

18
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:56.160
Let's get started.

19
00:00:58.240 --> 00:01:03.730
The primary take away from this, test
takers, is for the supplier management.

20
00:01:03.730 --> 00:01:07.740
Its primary purpose is to obtain value for
money, so

21
00:01:07.740 --> 00:01:10.400
you can highlight those words,
obtain value for money.

22
00:01:10.400 --> 00:01:13.160
You'll see it's also one of
the objectives, purpose and

23
00:01:13.160 --> 00:01:15.380
objectives are almost synonymous.

24
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:20.270
A little acronym check, if you see down
near the bottom, we get the supplier and

25
00:01:20.270 --> 00:01:24.250
contract management information system,
the SCMIS.

26
00:01:24.250 --> 00:01:29.260
A lot of these processes have their own
information systems and this is one for

27
00:01:29.260 --> 00:01:31.480
supplier management, right?

28
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:36.410
So the scope is supplier management
is you might imagine is to manage

29
00:01:36.410 --> 00:01:40.990
all suppliers that help a service provider
deliver services to their customers.

30
00:01:40.990 --> 00:01:43.150
So a supplier could be someone
that delivers hardware,

31
00:01:43.150 --> 00:01:47.800
could be someone that delivers
software development services.

32
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:50.880
Any number of things can
be delivered by a supplier.

33
00:01:50.880 --> 00:01:52.520
Managing those contracts,

34
00:01:52.520 --> 00:01:57.550
making sure that the supplier's performing
up to speed as agreed in the contracts.

35
00:01:57.550 --> 00:02:01.785
Renegotiating those contracts,
punishing contractors if they don't,

36
00:02:01.785 --> 00:02:03.677
rewarding them if they do, etc.

37
00:02:03.677 --> 00:02:09.792
The supplier management process is going
to be overseeing those activities, right?

38
00:02:09.792 --> 00:02:12.820
Including the management of any
subcontracts that might be in play.

39
00:02:14.555 --> 00:02:17.650
Another key takeaway academically again,
for test takers,

40
00:02:17.650 --> 00:02:22.810
is the supplier management process
needs to evaluate a scheme or

41
00:02:22.810 --> 00:02:25.780
create a scheme of categorizing suppliers.

42
00:02:25.780 --> 00:02:27.266
You can see from the graphic here that,

43
00:02:27.266 --> 00:02:32.630
just kind of wanna continue down the lower
left, you get commodity suppliers.

44
00:02:32.630 --> 00:02:35.600
And in the upper right,
you get the strategic suppliers.

45
00:02:35.600 --> 00:02:42.330
So, Daniel, a commodity supplier,
just as an example would be a perhaps.

46
00:02:42.330 --> 00:02:46.302
And what's gonna happen if someone decides
they're not gonna deliver toner cartridge

47
00:02:46.302 --> 00:02:47.855
to your company anymore?

48
00:02:47.855 --> 00:02:50.140
>> I'd have a hard time
getting those print jobs done.

49
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:53.512
>> Yeah, but what are you gonna
do to replace that supplier?

50
00:02:53.512 --> 00:02:55.390
>> I guess I could search the web for
a competitor.

51
00:02:55.390 --> 00:02:57.280
>> Yeah, or
just go down the street to staples for

52
00:02:57.280 --> 00:02:59.230
a day until you figure out
who the supplier might be.

53
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:00.940
So, it's not that they're that critical.

54
00:03:00.940 --> 00:03:02.670
I mean you need to print, obviously.

55
00:03:02.670 --> 00:03:05.320
But if a supplier of a commodity

56
00:03:05.320 --> 00:03:08.650
type supply is delivering
something you can use to replace.

57
00:03:08.650 --> 00:03:09.760
>> There's always somebody else.

58
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:11.200
>> Yeah, there's always someone else.

59
00:03:11.200 --> 00:03:15.240
But look at the other end of that
continuum, like a strategic supplier.

60
00:03:15.240 --> 00:03:18.168
What would be a strategic supplier for
perhaps ITProTV,

61
00:03:18.168 --> 00:03:20.410
what would be a strategic supplier?

62
00:03:20.410 --> 00:03:23.190
If they don't succeed,
you're not succeeding.

63
00:03:23.190 --> 00:03:27.560
>> Let's see here,
probably our stream provider.

64
00:03:27.560 --> 00:03:28.790
>> There you go, right.

65
00:03:28.790 --> 00:03:30.800
So that's obviously someone
you care a lot about.

66
00:03:30.800 --> 00:03:33.120
That's not a toner
cartridge kind of supplier,

67
00:03:33.120 --> 00:03:35.810
that's someone that helps you get
your job done here at ITProTV.

68
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:38.500
So that's really the kind of
this continuum if you will.

69
00:03:38.500 --> 00:03:41.450
Commodity at one end,
strategic suppliers at the other.

70
00:03:41.450 --> 00:03:42.350
And you see, somewhere in

71
00:03:42.350 --> 00:03:45.020
the middle you've got what's
called tactical suppliers.

72
00:03:45.020 --> 00:03:48.940
Again, test takers, this is good
to understand this continuum or

73
00:03:48.940 --> 00:03:50.760
this categorization if you will,

74
00:03:50.760 --> 00:03:54.780
of suppliers and be able to pick
them out on a multiple choice.

75
00:03:54.780 --> 00:04:00.349
They'll describe a supplier and you kind
of put them in the right category, right?

76
00:04:00.349 --> 00:04:04.365
Okay, good.

77
00:04:04.365 --> 00:04:08.302
Supplier policy is also another aspect
of supplier management needs to be

78
00:04:08.302 --> 00:04:09.790
concerned with.

79
00:04:09.790 --> 00:04:14.160
This often manifests itself in stuff
like preferred vendors, right?

80
00:04:14.160 --> 00:04:15.840
So an organization will setup

81
00:04:16.900 --> 00:04:21.640
a shorter list of here's where you can
go get this kind of service, right?

82
00:04:21.640 --> 00:04:25.110
We get our service from these three
suppliers and only these three suppliers.

83
00:04:25.110 --> 00:04:29.680
Or we get our toner cartridges from
these five suppliers and nobody else.

84
00:04:29.680 --> 00:04:33.000
But saying that preferred
vendors could be part of policy.

85
00:04:33.000 --> 00:04:38.450
How you go about procuring suppliers
could also be part of policy,

86
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:41.088
the processes, etc., okay.

87
00:04:41.088 --> 00:04:43.496
All right.

88
00:04:43.496 --> 00:04:47.310
Now to the other process
service catalog management.

89
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:51.889
You may recall from service strategy
that we described the service portfolio.

90
00:04:51.889 --> 00:04:54.290
The service portfolio had three parts,

91
00:04:54.290 --> 00:04:59.140

as you update the service?

428
00:23:05.000 --> 00:23:06.730
Do you need to go back and
touch your documents?

429
00:23:06.730 --> 00:23:09.000
So knowing that those are interrelated.

430
00:23:09.000 --> 00:23:12.080
If you changed the architecture, maybe
you need to go back to that architectural

431
00:23:12.080 --> 00:23:14.300
diagram and then tweak it, right?

432
00:23:14.300 --> 00:23:19.546
So the inter-relationship among these
assets is also part of the goals or

433
00:23:19.546 --> 00:23:21.440
purpose of SACM, right?

434
00:23:21.440 --> 00:23:25.680
And the scope,
as we've described before is

435
00:23:25.680 --> 00:23:28.840
making sure that you understand these CIs,
you have them under control.

436
00:23:28.840 --> 00:23:33.630
All things that you care about and
want to control are a CI, okay.

437
00:23:35.780 --> 00:23:40.220
Now it is a logical configuration model,
as I mentioned before,

438
00:23:40.220 --> 00:23:44.140
you're not controlling your
employees through SACM,

439
00:23:44.140 --> 00:23:47.220
you're controlling the attributes
related to these employees.

440
00:23:47.220 --> 00:23:51.870
It's not that you're controlling
the servers that are in that CMDB.

441
00:23:51.870 --> 00:23:55.650
You're controlling the attributes
related to that server, right?

442
00:23:55.650 --> 00:23:58.700
So it's a logical model,
not a physical one.

443
00:23:58.700 --> 00:23:59.400
Right?

444
00:23:59.400 --> 00:24:03.426
And certainly, you're trying to reflect
physical reality that the server has its

445
00:24:03.426 --> 00:24:07.610
application installed but it is a logical
construction, not a physical one.

446
00:24:07.610 --> 00:24:09.760
Right?
And that's what this graphic is trying to

447
00:24:09.760 --> 00:24:12.830
show you, how these things
are inter related to each other and

448
00:24:12.830 --> 00:24:18.462
the ability to show their
interrelationships is a key goal of SACM.

449
00:24:18.462 --> 00:24:19.570
Okay.

450
00:24:19.570 --> 00:24:25.810
And as we described before,
the CMS is part of the larger SKMS and

451
00:24:25.810 --> 00:24:28.890
this graphic is also
reinforcing that CMDB,

452
00:24:28.890 --> 00:24:35.030
it's configuration management databases
are inside the CMS or a subset of the CMS.

453
00:24:35.030 --> 00:24:38.590
So, understanding that relationship,
the biggest one's the SKMS,

454
00:24:38.590 --> 00:24:43.580
I described it earlier as the SKMS is like
the ocean The CMS might be considered

455
00:24:43.580 --> 00:24:47.550
a great big ship and the CMDBs
are containers on top of that ship.

456
00:24:47.550 --> 00:24:49.904
You can consider it that way,
too, if that helps you.

457
00:24:49.904 --> 00:24:52.130
Okay, all right.

458
00:24:52.130 --> 00:24:54.370
Now, a very specific type of

459
00:24:56.920 --> 00:25:02.150
asset is software,
whether it's off the shelf purchased or

460
00:25:02.150 --> 00:25:05.050
something you've homegrown
inside the organization.

461
00:25:05.050 --> 00:25:08.350
Keeping up with your software assets,
so those software CIs.

462
00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:14.100
They have a very special location and
why IT calls the definitive media library.

463
00:25:14.100 --> 00:25:16.020
Now, if you look at the graphic,
it's kinda cute.

464
00:25:17.640 --> 00:25:21.030
At least it's cute in terms
of going back in time.

465
00:25:21.030 --> 00:25:22.035
>> Not like a puppy.

466
00:25:22.035 --> 00:25:23.930
[LAUGH]
>> Not like that, right.

467
00:25:23.930 --> 00:25:28.270
But look this is actually a physical
cabinet with floppy disks and

468
00:25:28.270 --> 00:25:31.515
disk drives in it and tape reels.

469
00:25:31.515 --> 00:25:32.020
Right?

470
00:25:32.020 --> 00:25:33.463
>> That's what we use here.

471
00:25:33.463 --> 00:25:35.697
>> Are you still using
those little floppies?

472
00:25:35.697 --> 00:25:39.495
[CROSSTALK] And really I didn't know about
for a long time what these might be,

473
00:25:39.495 --> 00:25:41.023
these little boxes at the top.

474
00:25:41.023 --> 00:25:45.237
But someone said maybe they're
boxes of Fortran cards,

475
00:25:45.237 --> 00:25:49.130
to configure your assets
on a mainframe computer.

476
00:25:49.130 --> 00:25:50.250
So maybe that's what that is.

477
00:25:50.250 --> 00:25:55.020
So obviously we've kind of grown
beyond the physical cabinet

478
00:25:55.020 --> 00:25:58.850
idea where these assets
are more stored electronically.

479
00:25:58.850 --> 00:26:03.090
But the idea of having these
in control in a known place

480
00:26:03.090 --> 00:26:05.760
is what a Definitive of
Media Library is about, right?

481
00:26:05.760 --> 00:26:11.430
So you know where the latest version
of Adobe Acrobat is stored and

482
00:26:11.430 --> 00:26:15.390
when you're configuring a desktop for
your employees you get it from that

483
00:26:15.390 --> 00:26:18.550
definitive source and
you load it up right?

484
00:26:18.550 --> 00:26:19.540
Those kinds of things.

485
00:26:19.540 --> 00:26:24.560
Or you know where your images are for
operating system, etc., all right.

486
00:26:24.560 --> 00:26:28.720
So it's the definitive source or
the Definitive Media Library, it's

487
00:26:28.720 --> 00:26:35.170
the definitive location of your software
assets, right, for control purposes.

488
00:26:35.170 --> 00:26:37.210
And it includes control documentation.

489
00:26:37.210 --> 00:26:38.650
How many times it's been installed,

490
00:26:38.650 --> 00:26:42.180
on what assets including license control,
right?

491
00:26:42.180 --> 00:26:44.790
And again once upon a time it was
a physical construction, right?

492
00:26:44.790 --> 00:26:45.450
It was a box.

493
00:26:45.450 --> 00:26:46.630
It was a cabinet and

494
00:26:46.630 --> 00:26:50.870
there was actually physical license
agreements in that cabinet, right?

495
00:26:50.870 --> 00:26:55.050
And you showed your control on physical
checklists and those kind of things.

496
00:26:55.050 --> 00:26:56.730
Even though it's more electronic now,

497
00:26:56.730 --> 00:27:00.620
this construction of Definitive Media
Library is still in play and that you need

498
00:27:00.620 --> 00:27:04.930
to have a Definitive Media Library to
successfully manage your software assets.

499
00:27:04.930 --> 00:27:08.900
And remember, it's not just for
off the shelf assets like if you buy

500
00:27:08.900 --> 00:27:14.460
Microsoft Word or Office, or
any other type of asset, software asset.

501
00:27:14.460 --> 00:27:18.028
It could be those that you home grow,
your self developed software and

502
00:27:18.028 --> 00:27:19.912
you have your known versions there.

503
00:27:19.912 --> 00:27:24.865
So it's just a very special repository for
the very special assets called software,

504
00:27:24.865 --> 00:27:26.530
Definitive Media Library.

505
00:27:28.450 --> 00:27:32.010
That concluded our first part
of service transition, and

506
00:27:32.010 --> 00:27:35.350
remember we did the overall picture,
transition planning and

507
00:27:35.350 --> 00:27:38.320
support, that processes is the mother hen.

508
00:27:38.320 --> 00:27:43.640
We talked about knowledge management, DIKW
data, information, knowledge and wisdom.

509
00:27:43.640 --> 00:27:50.400
We also reinforced that it engenders
this great big thing called the SKMS.

510
00:27:50.400 --> 00:27:52.000
We talked about SACUM and

511
00:27:52.000 --> 00:27:57.300
it's ability to bring about a CMS,
a configuration management system

512
00:27:57.300 --> 00:28:01.940
with multiple configuration management
databases or CMDBs inside of it.

513
00:28:01.940 --> 00:28:05.550
We've got two more processes to go,
we'll pick it up in the next episode.

514
00:28:05.550 --> 00:28:06.420
>> Awesome stuff Terry.

515
00:28:06.420 --> 00:28:08.610
Well, thanks for
getting us through part one.

516
00:28:08.610 --> 00:28:12.080
Unfortunately, our time for
this episode has expired but don't worry,

517
00:28:12.080 --> 00:28:15.770
part two is coming right away and
if you're watching this live,

518
00:28:15.770 --> 00:28:20.220
we'll be right back and if not you can
have us right back any time you want

519
00:28:20.220 --> 00:28:22.161
because it's a recording and
you can watch it.

520
00:28:22.161 --> 00:28:23.140
[LAUGH] So a lot of good times there.

521
00:28:23.140 --> 00:28:25.020
Terry we look forward to seeing you there.

522
00:28:25.020 --> 00:28:27.180
We look forward to seeing you
good folks there as well.

523
00:28:27.180 --> 00:28:30.134
But as for this one we're gonna go
ahead and sign off for ITProTV.

524
00:28:30.134 --> 00:28:31.498
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

525
00:28:31.498 --> 00:28:32.446
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

526
00:28:32.446 --> 00:28:34.791
>> We'll see you next time.

527
00:28:34.791 --> 00:28:43.270
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry continue to discuss Service Transition, the third of five Service Lifecycle stages. They pick back up by finishing their look at the last three processes that comprise Service Transition. This includes Change Management, Release and Deployment Management, and Knowledge Management.
episodes.title: Service Transition Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.086 --> 00:00:10.086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.084 --> 00:00:16.324
All right, greetings folks, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.324 --> 00:00:17.803
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:17.803 --> 00:00:21.680
in today's episode we are continuing
on with our ITIL foundation series.

5
00:00:21.680 --> 00:00:24.460
Joining us in the studio today
is our good friend, our mentor,

6
00:00:24.460 --> 00:00:27.880
our guiding star in this endeavor,
Mr. Terry Decker.

7
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:28.780
Terry welcome back sir.

8
00:00:28.780 --> 00:00:29.340
How's it going?

9
00:00:29.340 --> 00:00:30.290
>> It's good to be back.

10
00:00:30.290 --> 00:00:31.132
Yeah, happy to be here.

11
00:00:31.132 --> 00:00:34.060
You'll recall that we had
service transition queued up for

12
00:00:34.060 --> 00:00:36.880
our last episode and
we went through three of the processes.

13
00:00:36.880 --> 00:00:39.750
We went through transition planning and
support, that mother hen.

14
00:00:39.750 --> 00:00:43.210
Knowledge management and service asset and
configuration management.

15
00:00:43.210 --> 00:00:46.390
We've got two more to go,
change management and release and

16
00:00:46.390 --> 00:00:47.220
deployment management.

17
00:00:47.220 --> 00:00:48.500
So that's where we are.

18
00:00:48.500 --> 00:00:51.490
And where we're going,
all right lets dig in.

19
00:00:51.490 --> 00:00:55.670
Actually before talking about
change in any kind of detail or

20
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:58.845
release management in any kind of detail,
I'd liked to do a little compare and

21
00:00:58.845 --> 00:01:02.590
contrast between change and
release at the point of management.

22
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:07.460
This may be my own baggage but
I know for a good amount of time I was

23
00:01:07.460 --> 00:01:12.440
confused over where changed end, and where
release started and how they integrated.

24
00:01:12.440 --> 00:01:15.930
And this graphic here really
does do a good amount

25
00:01:15.930 --> 00:01:18.050
of justice to how they're integrated.

26
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:19.390
It's not like one ends and

27
00:01:19.390 --> 00:01:22.960
the other one picks up,
they often get back together, right?

28
00:01:22.960 --> 00:01:27.850
So they're an iterative interaction
between change and release management.

29
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:33.340
And the simplest way to describe this is
changed management is the authorization

30
00:01:34.430 --> 00:01:38.140
body, if you will, and release and
deployment is the execution arm,

31
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:44.435
they get it done, in RACI terms, R, A,
C, I that is, you may consider changes,

32
00:01:44.435 --> 00:01:49.930
the accountable, and
release as the responsible.

33
00:01:49.930 --> 00:01:53.580
Change, authorizes things to happen,
release and

34
00:01:53.580 --> 00:01:56.120
deployment management get it done, right?

35
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:57.690
And it does so iteratively.

36
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:02.680
As you can see any given change
might have several phases.

37
00:02:02.680 --> 00:02:03.310
Right?

38
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:07.200
And they describe here the phases
of release and deployment process.

39
00:02:07.200 --> 00:02:09.730
So we're kinda teaching a little
bit of both here at the same time.

40
00:02:09.730 --> 00:02:14.000
But imagine if you will, the change

41
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:18.900
management process entertaining 10 changes
that come to their attention, right?

42
00:02:18.900 --> 00:02:21.660
Change management process is
looking at 10 changes and

43
00:02:21.660 --> 00:02:25.140
they send those 10 changes down to
release and deployment management.

44
00:02:25.140 --> 00:02:27.010
So hey plan these for us.

45
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:30.340
Right so
they authorize the release planning.

46
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:33.570
So even that's a milestone
that gets approved.

47
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:36.747
Right they may look, maybe they got
15 change requests, and they say,

48
00:02:36.747 --> 00:02:39.760
well we're not gonna do those 5,
and they reject them out of hand.

49
00:02:39.760 --> 00:02:42.580
Maybe they're too expensive or
they're covered by some other change

50
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:45.640
that was requested six weeks
ago that sort of thing.

51
00:02:45.640 --> 00:02:49.536
But they send 10 of those changes down
to release and deployment, release and

52
00:02:49.536 --> 00:02:53.435
deployment looks at those 10 changes and
decides to package them.

53
00:02:53.435 --> 00:02:55.655
These five are kind of break fix items and

54
00:02:55.655 --> 00:02:59.005
these other five are enhancements,
some sort of enhancements.

55
00:02:59.005 --> 00:03:00.735
So they divide them up and

56
00:03:00.735 --> 00:03:05.430
they send those packages back along with
a recommendation for when they could be

57
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:09.210
built when they could be deployed
eventually and tested etcetera.

58
00:03:09.210 --> 00:03:11.877
Right.
So they've sent back a plan to the change

59
00:03:11.877 --> 00:03:16.656
authority and change management and change
management looks at the two packages and

60
00:03:16.656 --> 00:03:20.160
says, yeah we like the timing
of these break fix things.

61
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:24.580
We go ahead and
approve you to build and to test those.

62
00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:25.080
Right?

63
00:03:25.080 --> 00:03:29.290
So there's another milestone that's met,
right?

64
00:03:29.290 --> 00:03:30.770
And back and forth, they go.

65
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:34.190
So now you got two packages on
two separate timelines, right?

66
00:03:34.190 --> 00:03:39.860
One's the enhancements, one's the break
fix and they're now managed as a group

67
00:03:39.860 --> 00:03:43.650
that will be managed together and release
and deployment's doing all that hard work

68
00:03:43.650 --> 00:03:48.490
of planning, building it, testing it,
and eventually deploying it, right.

69
00:03:48.490 --> 00:03:51.250
In an iterative fashion,
then, Change Management and

70
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:55.940
Release Management are interacting,
right, along these milestones.

71
00:03:55.940 --> 00:04:00.370
Change being the authorizing process,
release and

72
00:04:00.370 --> 00:04:05.340
deployment being the execution process,
actually getting it done, okay?

73
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:06.550
So it's moving forward then.

74
00:04:08.440 --> 00:04:13.220
Change management then, the focus now is
to control the life cycle of all stages,

75
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:14.480
all changes, I should say,

76
00:04:14.480 --> 00:04:18.350
from that's time it's requested to
the time it's ultimately deployed.

77
00:04:18.350 --> 00:04:22.130
And tied up in a nice neat bow, right.

78
00:04:22.130 --> 00:04:26.920
And the goal is to enable beneficial
changes, right do no harm.

79
00:04:26.920 --> 00:04:29.970
Make sure you're doing benefit when
you're bringing those changes in, right.

80
00:04:29.970 --> 00:04:33.280
It could be something small,
it could be something big.

81
00:04:33.280 --> 00:04:38.610
Change management is not just focused
on the day to day grind of change,

82
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:39.700
like break fix things.

83
00:04:39.700 --> 00:04:45.531
It could be huge things, big changes
to services, that is the scope, okay.

84
00:04:49.819 --> 00:04:51.275
All configuration Items.

85
00:04:51.275 --> 00:04:53.695
Remember we learned
when we discussed SAKUM

86
00:04:53.695 --> 00:04:57.405
that CIs are those service assets
that you wanna keep under control.

87
00:04:58.475 --> 00:05:00.915
Change management is
that method of control.

88
00:05:00.915 --> 00:05:02.140
Once you've identified them,

89
00:05:02.140 --> 00:05:06.210
changed management is going to make sure
they're changed in a controlled fashion.

90
00:05:06.210 --> 00:05:08.930
Right?
They could

91
00:05:08.930 --> 00:05:12.790
be physical assets like servers and
databases and applications.

92
00:05:12.790 --> 00:05:16.020
They could be documentation assets, right?

93
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:19.020
What you've determine to be a CI
is something you determined to be

94
00:05:19.020 --> 00:05:19.896
under change control, right.

95
00:05:21.622 --> 00:05:26.180
New and change services,
retired services, technology, management,

96
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:31.210
anything that you consider a CI can be in
the scope of changed management, right.

97
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:35.930
There are some things you
might consider out of scope.

98
00:05:35.930 --> 00:05:39.280
There's changes that happen every day
that perhaps aren't in scope with change

99
00:05:39.280 --> 00:05:41.360
management, you determine you
don't need to control those,

100
00:05:41.360 --> 00:05:43.960
you trust the process
that's working just fine.

101
00:05:43.960 --> 00:05:46.030
That's organizationally
defined as you see fit.

102
00:05:46.030 --> 00:05:52.340
Okay, in the organization, okay.

103
00:05:52.340 --> 00:05:55.720
Now gonna pick up some words
here as we go as always.

104
00:05:55.720 --> 00:05:58.510
On the next couple of slides,
we're gonna be learning some vocabulary.

105
00:05:58.510 --> 00:06:01.570
One of the vocabulary words, one of
the things you need to commit to memory

106
00:06:01.570 --> 00:06:05.260
is what is the definition of a change
proposal, or what is a change proposal?

107
00:06:06.470 --> 00:06:09.820
Do you recall we talked
about a business case?

108
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:15.890
Right a business case was a justification
for a significant item of expense.

109
00:06:15.890 --> 00:06:18.780
And we kind of hashed around
what's significant, right?

110
00:06:18.780 --> 00:06:22.240
For one organization,
$5,000 might be significant, for

111
00:06:22.240 --> 00:06:23.560
another one it might be $50,000, right.

112
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:28.030
You can kind of have those
different place and significance.

113
00:06:28.030 --> 00:06:32.890
But a change proposal is at
the same scale as a business case.

114
00:06:32.890 --> 00:06:36.630
A business case is for
a significant item of expense.

115
00:06:36.630 --> 00:06:41.670
A change proposal is for a significant
size change, or impactful change.

116
00:06:41.670 --> 00:06:43.730
So, it's something big, right?

117
00:06:43.730 --> 00:06:48.260
It's not your day to day request for
change like I want the button to be blue

118
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:53.719
instead of red or I want to fix the bug
that you found last week,right?

119
00:06:53.719 --> 00:06:58.480
Those tend to be the requests for
change in the change management scope.

120
00:06:58.480 --> 00:07:02.410
Change proposal are also in the change
management they just happen to be bigger.

121
00:07:02.410 --> 00:07:06.400
So they may get passed back
up to service strategy.

122
00:07:06.400 --> 00:07:10.320
And service strategy would publish or
would put out the change proposals.

123
00:07:10.320 --> 00:07:13.273
Says yes this is big we
are wanting this to happen and

124
00:07:13.273 --> 00:07:15.890
it's something, again significant size.

125
00:07:15.890 --> 00:07:20.080
>> So
would a good description of that be say,

126
00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:23.730
we've got a website, and like you said,
I want the button to blue instead of gray,

127
00:07:23.730 --> 00:07:25.520
I think it looks better,
it's more attractive.

128
00:07:25.520 --> 00:07:26.733
That's the minor thing.

129
00:07:26.733 --> 00:07:32.417
Whereas, we're using Microsoft IIS to
run our website, let's move to Apache?

130

00:11:03.910 --> 00:11:07.840

00:11:18.490 --> 00:11:19.711

00:11:29.059 --> 00:11:33.300

Normal changes.

Emergency, Standard, and Normal.

A change model.

I'd like to reintroduce the word,

00:14:25.645 --> 00:14:27.730
ITIL uses the word model a lot.

If you just take out the noun

You could also do the same

A problem model, a predefined steps

00:14:57.200 --> 00:14:58.660
A request model.

00:14:58.660 --> 00:15:01.957

So, it's the how you take on

00:15:13.570 --> 00:15:17.180

00:15:19.710 --> 00:15:20.440
Right.

00:15:25.359 --> 00:15:26.580

Enhancements, however

00:15:39.180 --> 00:15:40.745

00:15:40.745 --> 00:15:43.299
So you have a different model for

00:15:43.299 --> 00:15:47.523
Maybe have a model for

00:15:47.523 --> 00:15:53.244

00:15:53.244 --> 00:15:58.172

00:15:58.172 --> 00:16:01.770
different particular kinds of changes.

00:16:01.770 --> 00:16:03.690
Okay, that's a change model.

00:16:03.690 --> 00:16:05.360
So it tells you the how.

00:16:05.360 --> 00:16:10.220
It also tells you the who, what,

00:16:10.220 --> 00:16:13.547
So a change model is going

00:16:13.547 --> 00:16:19.390

00:16:19.390 --> 00:16:22.984

00:16:22.984 --> 00:16:25.920
So there could be timing

00:16:25.920 --> 00:16:29.110
We could relearn that model a little

00:16:29.110 --> 00:16:31.170

00:16:31.170 --> 00:16:35.846
I wanna kinda introduce it now as

00:16:35.846 --> 00:16:38.019

00:16:39.879 --> 00:16:41.560

00:16:47.540 --> 00:16:53.480

00:17:24.468 --> 00:17:26.628

00:17:26.628 --> 00:17:28.710

00:17:36.060 --> 00:17:37.890

00:17:37.890 --> 00:17:41.940

331
00:17:41.940 --> 00:17:43.820
you have to have some
other plan in place for

00:17:43.820 --> 00:17:48.650
how you're gonna deal with

333
00:17:48.650 --> 00:17:52.360
It is something you do before
you realize it's failed, right?

334
00:17:53.470 --> 00:17:55.020
That's remediation planning.

00:17:55.020 --> 00:17:59.550
Again, you can equate it to back out

336
00:17:59.550 --> 00:18:04.050
Just note that ITIL gives it

337
00:18:04.050 --> 00:18:12.470
remediation planning as

338
00:18:12.470 --> 00:18:16.108
Change advisory board,

00:18:16.108 --> 00:18:21.620

00:18:21.620 --> 00:18:24.250

00:18:24.250 --> 00:18:26.950

00:18:26.950 --> 00:18:30.950

00:18:33.275 --> 00:18:37.615
It authorizes those various milestones for

00:18:37.615 --> 00:18:41.765
They authorize the planning, they
authorize the building and the testing.

00:18:41.765 --> 00:18:45.915
They eventually authorize the deployment,

347
00:18:45.915 --> 00:18:48.750
And closure as it turns out.

348
00:18:49.780 --> 00:18:53.720
The change advisory board is that
group of people that get together

00:18:53.720 --> 00:18:58.920
on a regular basis and
determine the authority

to move on with a change whether it be for

00:19:03.650 --> 00:19:07.100
building and testing, whether it be for

352
00:19:07.100 --> 00:19:12.030
So you're looking at existing records,

00:19:12.030 --> 00:19:16.608
changes coming out at their different

meaning is effectively the authorization

00:19:21.780 --> 00:19:23.340

00:19:23.340 --> 00:19:26.590

Someone representing the processes

Someone representing the customers or

00:19:39.730 --> 00:19:43.450
It can be rather elastic or

00:19:43.450 --> 00:19:47.880
It kinda depends on the topic of that cab

00:19:51.530 --> 00:19:56.380
that gets together to manage

365
00:19:56.380 --> 00:19:59.250
An emergency CAB however,

00:19:59.250 --> 00:20:02.950

00:22:51.240 --> 00:22:52.560

employment management the answer

00:26:22.965 --> 00:26:23.565

Very good example.

00:26:24.365 --> 00:26:25.947
Good answer, right.

517
00:27:00.470 --> 00:27:04.970
Wiki style format that everybody knows and
loves, and it was highly successful.

518
00:27:04.970 --> 00:27:06.020
Very good.

519
00:27:06.020 --> 00:27:10.090
>> I've seen it implemented
more as a database.

520
00:27:10.090 --> 00:27:13.211
A relational database with a nice
good search engine on top of it.

521
00:27:13.211 --> 00:27:15.830
>> Right.
>> With index entries such

522
00:27:15.830 --> 00:27:17.210
as a Wiki might do.

523
00:27:17.210 --> 00:27:20.356
But rather than have the links and
stuff like a Wiki does, it was a search

524
00:27:20.356 --> 00:27:24.340
engine that then gave you a bunch of
results and then you go pick on those.

525
00:27:24.340 --> 00:27:27.370
Various ways to skin this cat.

526
00:27:27.370 --> 00:27:28.270
Very good approach there.
But

527
00:27:28.270 --> 00:27:32.680
the concept is, get these known errors
identified, get them documented, and

528
00:27:32.680 --> 00:27:36.510
make it accessible to the service
desk to speed up instant resolution.

529
00:27:36.510 --> 00:27:37.010
Very good.

530
00:27:38.880 --> 00:27:43.932
All right, problem management,
as you can see here also has a work flow.

531
00:27:43.932 --> 00:27:48.550
Not gonna dive too deep into this
particular details of this, but

532
00:27:48.550 --> 00:27:52.010
I do wanna show at a high
level that problem management

533
00:27:52.010 --> 00:27:56.010
could certainly interact with
other processes and tool sets.

534
00:27:56.010 --> 00:28:00.940
As an example, the problem once identified
could be loaded into the CMS or

535
00:28:00.940 --> 00:28:01.960
identified in the CMS.

536
00:28:01.960 --> 00:28:07.000
So if you've got a problem with server
XYZ, then the problem records will

537
00:28:07.000 --> 00:28:12.198
be associated with server XYZ in the CMS,
and overtime you could do trend analysis.

538
00:28:12.198 --> 00:28:15.350
Unless servers had a lot of problems
over the course of this year.

539
00:28:15.350 --> 00:28:18.380
Maybe it's time to put that one up the
past year, or something like that, right.

540
00:28:21.190 --> 00:28:25.590
Obviously, interacting with
incident management is a pretty

541
00:28:25.590 --> 00:28:30.830
common interaction because problems are
trying to resolve incidents that recur,

542
00:28:30.830 --> 00:28:35.070
you could have an approach here to
interact with incident management through

543
00:28:35.070 --> 00:28:40.190
that known error database
as we just discussed.

544
00:28:40.190 --> 00:28:42.895
Moving down the line once you
determine the root cause, and

545
00:28:42.895 --> 00:28:46.075
maybe you can fix that cause by
implementing some sort of change,

546
00:28:46.075 --> 00:28:48.645
then problem management can raise
that request for change and

547
00:28:48.645 --> 00:28:52.355
make sure change management kicks
off what it needs to do, right?

548
00:28:52.355 --> 00:28:55.710
So problem management can lead
out to many other processes and

549
00:28:55.710 --> 00:28:58.870
many other aspects, wherever it may lead.

550
00:28:58.870 --> 00:29:02.640
In fact, problem management, if you
have a good problem management regime,

551
00:29:02.640 --> 00:29:06.590
you can discern problems upstream, right?

552
00:29:06.590 --> 00:29:09.540
Maybe you have bad design
that keeps recurring so

553
00:29:09.540 --> 00:29:12.710
you need to go back to service design and
try to shore up those processes.

554
00:29:12.710 --> 00:29:14.680
Maybe even strategy is kind of flawed.

555
00:29:14.680 --> 00:29:16.520
You don't have good financial reporting.

556
00:29:16.520 --> 00:29:19.380
I mean all kinds of things
problem management could dig up.

557
00:29:19.380 --> 00:29:22.490
So wherever the trail leads,
problem management can give you an answer.

558
00:29:22.490 --> 00:29:25.150
The root cause for this was x.

559
00:29:25.150 --> 00:29:31.050
Go to where x is, mark that spot and
start trying to improve it, right?

560
00:29:31.050 --> 00:29:33.335
Finally, about major problems.

561
00:29:33.335 --> 00:29:36.760
You could have major problems usually
associated with major incidents.

562
00:29:36.760 --> 00:29:39.770
In fact, that's exactly how
I had put it in the past,

563
00:29:39.770 --> 00:29:43.970
was if there was a major incident,
we had a problem record.

564
00:29:43.970 --> 00:29:46.640
Because we want to know, we're gonna
get it back as soon as possible.

565
00:29:46.640 --> 00:29:49.390
But since it was a major incident,
we're gonna have a deep dive in

566
00:29:49.390 --> 00:29:54.190
that major incident, and do some root
cause analysis and root cause elimination.

567
00:29:54.190 --> 00:29:55.520
So it doesn't come back.

568
00:29:55.520 --> 00:29:59.760
And hopefully do some proactive
root cause analysis as well so

569
00:29:59.760 --> 00:30:04.926
we can forestall those problems
in other ways for other services.

570
00:30:04.926 --> 00:30:08.700
All right, again, a good reminder that
problem management like the other

571
00:30:08.700 --> 00:30:15.050
processes are integrated across
multiple processes in ITIL.

572
00:30:15.050 --> 00:30:17.610
This is just a reminder that
it can go just about anywhere.

573
00:30:20.002 --> 00:30:21.990
>> All right,

574
00:30:21.990 --> 00:30:26.710
that's a good place to stop here with the
process definitions and understandings.

575
00:30:26.710 --> 00:30:28.720
We've gone through Incident problem.

576
00:30:28.720 --> 00:30:31.890
We've got Event Request and
Access Management to still up.

577
00:30:31.890 --> 00:30:33.490
We'll pick those up in another episode.

578
00:30:33.490 --> 00:30:34.350
>> Great stuff, Terry.

579
00:30:34.350 --> 00:30:37.910
Well thanks so much for explaining and
walking us through this, guiding us,

580
00:30:37.910 --> 00:30:39.370
cuz it's a lot of information.

581
00:30:39.370 --> 00:30:40.960
ITIL's got a lot of stuff
that we gotta know.

582
00:30:40.960 --> 00:30:42.770
Obviously tons of key concepts,

583
00:30:42.770 --> 00:30:46.210
definitions that we're just having
to bury into the old noodle.

584
00:30:46.210 --> 00:30:48.000
And you walking us through it and

585
00:30:48.000 --> 00:30:51.110
helping us make some sense out
of it all is very, very helpful.

586
00:30:51.110 --> 00:30:52.460
So we thank you for that.

587
00:30:52.460 --> 00:30:55.890
We thank you guys for watching today,
but we're out of time for

588
00:30:55.890 --> 00:30:58.200
this episode but don't fret.

589
00:30:58.200 --> 00:31:02.860
There is more when it comes to
service operations so be prepared for

590
00:31:02.860 --> 00:31:03.730
part II on that.

591
00:31:03.730 --> 00:31:04.880
Hopefully we'll see you there.

592
00:31:04.880 --> 00:31:06.880
That being said we're gonna go ahead and
sign off.

593
00:31:06.880 --> 00:31:09.317
For IT Pro TV I'm I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

594
00:31:09.317 --> 00:31:10.005
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

595
00:31:10.005 --> 00:31:12.012
>> And we'll see you next time.

596
00:31:12.012 --> 00:31:17.438
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry continue to discuss Service Operation, the fourth of five Service Lifecycle stages. Here they jump back in the conversation by looking at the last three Service Operation processes. This includes Event Management, Request Fulfillment, and Access Management. They also discuss the 4 functions; Service Desk, Technical Management, Application Management, and IT Operations Management.
episodes.title: Service Operation Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.835 --> 00:00:16.520
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
back to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:17.750
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:17.750 --> 00:00:22.170
in today's episode we are moving forward
with more in our ITIL Foundation series.

5
00:00:22.170 --> 00:00:25.830
Joining us back in the studio again
today for one of our famous part twos,

6
00:00:25.830 --> 00:00:28.730
is the man, the myth, the legend,
that is Terry Decker.

7
00:00:28.730 --> 00:00:30.280
Terry, welcome back sir, how's it going?

8
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:31.740
>> Glad to be here Daniel.

9
00:00:31.740 --> 00:00:34.190
Yep, as he said,
we covered a lot of ground so far.

10
00:00:34.190 --> 00:00:37.570
We've gotten a good portion
through service operations,

11
00:00:37.570 --> 00:00:40.480
want to pick up the rest
of that in this episode.

12
00:00:40.480 --> 00:00:43.370
We got two or three more process to go and

13
00:00:43.370 --> 00:00:48.300
four functions to discuss in this episode,
so a lot to learn, let's dig in.

14
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:50.510
We have a few processes yet to go.

15
00:00:50.510 --> 00:00:53.995
We have Event, Request Fulfillment,
and Access Management left to go.

16
00:00:53.995 --> 00:00:56.597
We've talked about Event
a little bit already, so

17
00:00:56.597 --> 00:01:00.925
this will be a shortchange one, and
then we got four functions after that.

18
00:01:00.925 --> 00:01:05.635
So, Event Management, to detect events,
make sense of them, and

19
00:01:05.635 --> 00:01:06.996
determine the appropriate control action.

20
00:01:08.147 --> 00:01:10.597
Remind ourselves what an event is though.

21
00:01:10.597 --> 00:01:17.437
An event is a change in state of
a CI that you care about, right?

22
00:01:17.437 --> 00:01:18.677
That's significant.

23
00:01:18.677 --> 00:01:20.548
A significant change of state.

24
00:01:20.548 --> 00:01:23.308
So, the detection is actually automated.

25
00:01:23.308 --> 00:01:25.048
So, the detection is there.

26
00:01:25.048 --> 00:01:27.148
Now we need to make sense of it,
and do something about it.

27
00:01:27.148 --> 00:01:31.448
The example I mentioned earlier was,
the disk is 75% full, right?

28
00:01:31.448 --> 00:01:36.029
That can be detected, a notification can
go out, someone can respond to that,

29
00:01:36.029 --> 00:01:39.769
and keep it from getting full
before the remedy's there, right?

30
00:01:39.769 --> 00:01:44.699
So detecting those changes of state
is what Event Management is about.

31
00:01:44.699 --> 00:01:50.090
Making sense of those changes of state and
doing the appropriate action, right?

32
00:01:50.090 --> 00:01:55.030
>> So basically, if the alert comes in,
okay, your disc is 75% full.

33
00:01:55.030 --> 00:02:00.220
And you go, well that's interesting
because yesterday it was only 10% full.

34
00:02:00.220 --> 00:02:02.050
You're thinking,
now I'm making sense of this.

35
00:02:02.050 --> 00:02:04.380
There's something happening
that's filling up my disk.

36
00:02:04.380 --> 00:02:09.230
If it's, wow, we've had that disk a long
time and now we just hit that 75% mark.

37
00:02:09.230 --> 00:02:13.901
I might start looking into upgrading
it to a larger disk because now you've

38
00:02:13.901 --> 00:02:15.910
reached maybe end of life or capacity.

39
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:16.940
>> Right.

40
00:02:16.940 --> 00:02:20.190
And keep in mind events can be for
component things, it can be for

41
00:02:20.190 --> 00:02:23.180
physical things like the data
center is getting hot.

42
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:26.230
So you got a temperature gauge
that triggers off an event so

43
00:02:26.230 --> 00:02:28.120
that you can get to the data
center quickly enough, right?

44
00:02:28.120 --> 00:02:29.970
It can be for lots of things.

45
00:02:29.970 --> 00:02:31.780
And sometimes it's just for
mundane things.

46
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:33.740
The batch file completed successfully.

47
00:02:34.760 --> 00:02:36.725
The backup was successful, right?

48
00:02:36.725 --> 00:02:40.420
You don't have to necessarily respond, but
you want to know that, that happened so

49
00:02:40.420 --> 00:02:44.540
you log the event, it's detected and
you can do something or

50
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:48.810
do nothing because it simply showed
success of something, right.

51
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:51.790
So that's a good segue
to the types of events

52
00:02:51.790 --> 00:02:53.960
that are in the scope of Event Management.

53
00:02:53.960 --> 00:02:57.140
And definitely worthy of memorization here

54
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:00.240
is that Event Management
has three types of events.

55
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:04.460
Informational events would just
indicate regular operation.

56
00:03:04.460 --> 00:03:07.330
Like I just mentioned,
the batch file completed successfully.

57
00:03:07.330 --> 00:03:08.560
The backup was successful.

58
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:12.260
Terry Decker logged in today, right?

59
00:03:12.260 --> 00:03:16.010
Usually, something like log-ins
are actually logged, automatically, right?

60
00:03:16.010 --> 00:03:17.480
It's not something you have to respond to.

61
00:03:17.480 --> 00:03:19.780
It's just information only, right?

62
00:03:19.780 --> 00:03:24.480
Now if that Terry Decker logged in today,
happened to coincide with the same morning

63
00:03:24.480 --> 00:03:29.030
that there was data theft, then having
a log of who logged in gives you your

64
00:03:29.030 --> 00:03:33.025
ability to do some forensic analysis of,
where did did Terry go when he logged in?

65
00:03:33.025 --> 00:03:36.585
Did he log into the HR database and
steal all the salary information, right?

66
00:03:36.585 --> 00:03:38.055
So information-
>> We're

67
00:03:38.055 --> 00:03:39.433
not gonna let that happen again are we?

68
00:03:39.433 --> 00:03:39.941
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

69
00:03:39.941 --> 00:03:40.646
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

70
00:03:40.646 --> 00:03:43.146
>> So informational events can become

71
00:03:43.146 --> 00:03:46.668
more significant later.
They may not be significant now but

72
00:03:46.668 --> 00:03:49.550
more important later on.

73
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:52.790
A Warning event is a warning
like the disk is 75% full,

74
00:03:52.790 --> 00:03:56.770
let's go and get that disk
freed up a little bit, right,

75
00:03:56.770 --> 00:04:00.480
before it actually causes problems,
that it's a 100% full.

76
00:04:00.480 --> 00:04:03.110
So a warning event is just that.

77
00:04:03.110 --> 00:04:04.675
It's giving you advance warning so

78
00:04:04.675 --> 00:04:09.450
that you can get in front of the problem
before it actually impacts users, right?

79
00:04:09.450 --> 00:04:13.870
And then an Exception event, well it's
too late, the disk is 100% full, right?

80
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:18.470
It already got there, the thing fell over,
or the data center's on

81
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:21.370
fire instead of it's just getting warm,
right, those kind of things.

82
00:04:21.370 --> 00:04:23.033
Those would be-
>> It's cold in there,

83
00:04:23.033 --> 00:04:24.045
we had to do something.

84
00:04:24.045 --> 00:04:25.338
[LAUGH]
>> Except sniffing,

85
00:04:25.338 --> 00:04:27.505
he built a little fire in the data center.

86
00:04:27.505 --> 00:04:28.200
>> That's right.

87
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:30.260
>> A weenie roast in
the data center this week.

88
00:04:30.260 --> 00:04:32.112
>> There was no policy that
said we couldn't do that.

89
00:04:32.112 --> 00:04:33.955
[LAUGH]
>> Very good.

90
00:04:33.955 --> 00:04:36.580
So that's Event Management.

91
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:41.590
Request Fulfillment,
also a fairly easy throw when you consider

92
00:04:41.590 --> 00:04:46.280
that request fulfillment is the process

93
00:04:46.280 --> 00:04:50.910
through which you satisfy or
handle common service requests.

94
00:04:50.910 --> 00:04:54.040
I mentioned some examples earlier
like I need a new headset.

95
00:04:54.040 --> 00:04:55.700
I need a mouse, right.

96
00:04:55.700 --> 00:05:00.460
I need more disk space, maybe that's
a common request of the server team,

97
00:05:00.460 --> 00:05:02.300
I need more disk space.

98
00:05:02.300 --> 00:05:07.300
I need a virtual machine, that may be
a common request that you standardize so

99
00:05:07.300 --> 00:05:10.700
that you can quickly satisfy
those kinds of requests.

100
00:05:10.700 --> 00:05:13.720
I need a restore, I need a backup,
those kind of things.

101
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:19.910
You might decide to standardize that type
of activity and put it behind the workflow

102
00:05:19.910 --> 00:05:25.320
so that people can easily request
those services ongoing basis, right?

103
00:05:26.590 --> 00:05:29.550
That's what Request Fulfillment is about.

104
00:05:29.550 --> 00:05:32.330
And then finally, last but
not the least, Access Management.

105
00:05:32.330 --> 00:05:34.988
Also fairly intuitive for most folks.

106
00:05:34.988 --> 00:05:39.040
Most folks at IT are already used to
logging in, and getting access to things.

107
00:05:39.040 --> 00:05:42.400
They're also used to logging in, and
not getting access to others, right?

108
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:46.280
There's certain things you have access to,
there's certain things they don't, right?

109
00:05:46.280 --> 00:05:48.400
Access Management is the process,

110
00:05:48.400 --> 00:05:51.320
that ensures that the right people
get access to things, right?

111
00:05:51.320 --> 00:05:53.040
So, they're managing
the group memberships,

112
00:05:53.040 --> 00:05:55.250
they're managing the resources, right?

113
00:05:55.250 --> 00:05:58.720
They are not,
I say what access is not doing.

114
00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:01.960
Access Management is not
determining who gets it,

115
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:04.110
they're just following a process, right?

116
00:06:04.110 --> 00:06:08.110
So, again I'm the employee that supposed
to have access to the HR database

117
00:06:08.110 --> 00:06:11.320
to review salaries,
I'm the Compensation Analyst.

118
00:06:11.320 --> 00:06:14.880
The HR Director perhaps,
is initiating that request.

119
00:06:14.880 --> 00:06:20.430
It goes through due diligence
to satisfy security policy.

120
00:06:20.430 --> 00:06:21.550
And eventually,

121
00:06:21.550 --> 00:06:24.360
I'm granted that access because it
followed that particular workflow.

122
00:06:24.360 --> 00:06:28.110
So Access Management, again,
fairly intuitive for most people.

123
00:06:28.110 --> 00:06:31.390
It's the operational extension
of the security policy or

124
00:06:31.390 --> 00:06:36.265
the security management
process that's upstream, okay.

125
00:06:38.180 --> 00:06:40.720
That's the five processes, right?

126
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:44.790
Incident, Problem, Event, Request
Fulfillment, and Access Management.

127
00:06:46.210 --> 00:06:48.590
And then next up are four functions.

128
00:06:48.590 --> 00:06:51.995
The four functions within,
as described by ITIL.

129
00:06:51.995 --> 00:06:58.120
Again, ITILs great at distilling
things into smaller parts.

130
00:06:58.120 --> 00:07:02.160
A Function you'll recall,
the definition of a function is

131
00:07:02.160 --> 00:07:06.340
a group of people with special skills and
tools, right?

132
00:07:06.340 --> 00:07:08.504
They're a finite set of people,
so to speak, right?

133
00:07:08.504 --> 00:07:12.018
And they have special talents,
they even have special expertise, and

134
00:07:12.018 --> 00:07:16.133
they also have special tools allowing them
to get what they are doing done, right?

135
00:07:16.133 --> 00:07:19.280
So, they divide it up into four.

136
00:07:19.280 --> 00:07:23.340
One of these functions happens
to have some sub-functions.

137
00:07:23.340 --> 00:07:24.360
So if you really want to look at it,

138
00:07:24.360 --> 00:07:27.110
there's six things to memorize here,
right?

139
00:07:27.110 --> 00:07:29.870
These four functions,
plus two sub-functions.

140
00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:31.730
We're gonna talk about each of these.

141
00:07:31.730 --> 00:07:35.020
But definitely worth committing to memory,
just as you see them on this page.

142
00:07:35.020 --> 00:07:37.940
What are the four functions,
what are the two sub-functions?

143
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:39.480
And we'll talk about them each in turn.

144
00:07:39.480 --> 00:07:41.650
Service Desk, Technical Management,

145
00:07:41.650 --> 00:07:44.640
Application Management,
IT Operations Management and

146
00:07:44.640 --> 00:07:49.530
its two sub-functions, IT Operations
Control and Facilities Management.

147
00:07:49.530 --> 00:07:51.340
We first start with Service Desk.

148
00:07:53.420 --> 00:07:58.065
Most folks also find this fairly
intuitive, because most IT organizations

149
00:07:58.065 --> 00:08:01.270
have a Service Desk,
sometimes called a Help Desk.

150
00:08:01.270 --> 00:08:05.456
It's not unusual for that to happen
in most IT departments now, so
