00:28:22.750 --> 00:28:27.460
We need to measure where we are,
a baseline, so we know where we wanna go.

571
00:28:27.460 --> 00:28:31.290
>> Kind of makes sense, if you don't
have any way to gauge whether or not,

572
00:28:31.290 --> 00:28:34.130
you're doing better or worse,
you're just spinning your wheels.

573
00:28:34.130 --> 00:28:35.681
>> Exactly right, and
it's a data driven approach.

574
00:28:35.681 --> 00:28:36.420
>> Yeah.

575
00:28:36.420 --> 00:28:38.990
>> And one you can easily
present executives to buy in on.

576
00:28:38.990 --> 00:28:42.502
I say easily, noting's easy, necessarily,
but you'd have a data driven approach,

577
00:28:42.502 --> 00:28:43.313
not just a feeling.

578
00:28:43.313 --> 00:28:47.170
It's something you can actually show,
so it becomes more methodical.

579
00:28:47.170 --> 00:28:48.860
A bit more scientific, if you will.

580
00:28:48.860 --> 00:28:50.880
Methodical approach to
improving your services.

581
00:28:50.880 --> 00:28:52.860
>> I like that.
You don't feel that you're doing better.

582
00:28:52.860 --> 00:28:54.660
You know you are doing better.

583
00:28:54.660 --> 00:28:55.575
>> Exactly right.

584
00:28:55.575 --> 00:28:57.830
So, that's CSI.

585
00:28:57.830 --> 00:28:58.960
Continued Service Improvement.

586
00:28:58.960 --> 00:29:01.940
Again, it was kinda a short
lesson in that, but

587
00:29:01.940 --> 00:29:04.340
it kinda portrays just
how important it is.

588
00:29:04.340 --> 00:29:08.953
CSI Is a critical cultural advancement,
if you will, that you can take on.

589
00:29:08.953 --> 00:29:14.227
And in fact, you can use CSI
principles in your adoption and

590
00:29:14.227 --> 00:29:17.290
adaptation of ITIL itself.

591
00:29:17.290 --> 00:29:20.910
>> Obviously CSI, very important for
us, if you wanna continue to grow.

592
00:29:20.910 --> 00:29:22.940
Want to continue to do better,
reach new markets,

593
00:29:22.940 --> 00:29:25.250
things of that nature,
this is what you're gonna need to do.

594
00:29:25.250 --> 00:29:26.674
And if you wanna pass the ITIL exam,

595
00:29:26.674 --> 00:29:29.347
you're gonna need to rote memorization
quite a few things there.

596
00:29:29.347 --> 00:29:32.900
So get the flash cards handy and
start working.

597
00:29:32.900 --> 00:29:35.660
I know it's not that fun,
but it does work very well.

598
00:29:35.660 --> 00:29:37.994
We always like to say around here,
repetition breeds retention.

599
00:29:37.994 --> 00:29:39.150
>> Exactly.

600
00:29:39.150 --> 00:29:41.240
>> So make sure you jump on that.

601
00:29:41.240 --> 00:29:42.680
Terry, awesome stuff today.

602
00:29:42.680 --> 00:29:46.730
Thank you so much for
enlightening us to the CSI model there.

603
00:29:46.730 --> 00:29:49.130
That being said,
looks like it's time for us to sign off.

604
00:29:49.130 --> 00:29:51.870
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

605
00:29:51.870 --> 00:29:52.870
>> Thanks, Terry Decker.

606
00:29:52.870 --> 00:29:53.429
>> We'll see you next time.

607
00:29:53.429 --> 00:30:00.839
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Terry reviews the Sample Paper C to help the ITIL Foundations candidate with some Exam Preparation.  This particular Sample Paper is also available at the Axelos website for download.
episodes.title: Exam Prep Sample Paper C
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.033 --> 00:00:01.129
[SOUND] Hello,

2
00:00:01.129 --> 00:00:06.799
we're here on ITIL Foundations to help
you with a little bit of exam prep.

3
00:00:06.799 --> 00:00:10.806
We're going to be focusing in on Sample
Paper C, and here to help us out and

4
00:00:10.806 --> 00:00:14.350
to take us through this is
gonna be Mister Terry Decker.

5
00:00:14.350 --> 00:00:16.620
Terry, tell us what we're doing here.

6
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:20.790
>> Well, this particular episode assumes
that you've gone through the course,

7
00:00:20.790 --> 00:00:22.540
that you've studied.

8
00:00:22.540 --> 00:00:26.340
And perhaps you've even gone through the
practice exam already, the Sample Paper C.

9
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:29.270
If not, that's okay,
this would be just fine.

10
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:32.550
I'm gonna go through, rather quickly,
these 40 questions, giving

11
00:00:32.550 --> 00:00:36.240
you the correct answer and giving you
some rationale for that correct answer.

12
00:00:36.240 --> 00:00:39.500
If you've forgotten,
these things are available for download.

13
00:00:39.500 --> 00:00:42.340
Just go up to the upper right-hand
corner of the interface and

14
00:00:42.340 --> 00:00:43.900
you can download these.

15
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:44.940
So let's dig in.

16
00:00:44.940 --> 00:00:48.900
First of all, just gonna be showing
you on the screen as these go through.

17
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:52.410
You'll see my smiling
face in the bottom there.

18
00:00:52.410 --> 00:00:54.659
Which is not a source of best practice?

19
00:00:59.369 --> 00:01:02.309
You may recall that
this was a graphic that

20
00:01:02.309 --> 00:01:06.680
in the upper left hand corner
it had sources of best practice.

21
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:09.630
And the other side it had
enablers of best practice.

22
00:01:09.630 --> 00:01:12.880
Technology is one of the enablers
along with people, right?

23
00:01:12.880 --> 00:01:14.910
But these others, standards,
academic research, and

24
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:18.150
internal experience is kinda
where ideas come from.

25
00:01:18.150 --> 00:01:21.310
And that's where sources of best
practice come from for those areas.

26
00:01:21.310 --> 00:01:24.204
So B is correct because it is
not a source of best practice.

27
00:01:24.204 --> 00:01:28.950
Okay, which three
are the characteristics of ITIL guidance

28
00:01:28.950 --> 00:01:31.378
that help make it successful?

29
00:01:31.378 --> 00:01:35.359
Pretty straightforward here,
it's just rote memorization.

30
00:01:35.359 --> 00:01:39.860
The answer is C, vendor neutral,
non-prescriptive, and best practice.

31
00:01:39.860 --> 00:01:43.929
Just pretty much straight up, nothing
really conceptual other than memorization

32
00:01:43.929 --> 00:01:46.089
here, but definitely worthy memorizing.

33
00:01:48.210 --> 00:01:52.270
What is the ITIL term for
costumers of an IT service provider

34
00:01:52.270 --> 00:01:55.810
who purchase services as
agreed in a legal contract?

35
00:01:57.420 --> 00:02:01.890
ITIL describes these as
external customers, right?

36
00:02:01.890 --> 00:02:04.370
Of course they're valued,
certainly not internal.

37
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:06.220
And the distinction between strategic or

38
00:02:06.220 --> 00:02:10.510
tactical customers is not
the operating principle here.

39
00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:11.427
External customers is the correct answer.

40
00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:16.947
Which is not defined as
part of every process?

41
00:02:19.256 --> 00:02:22.490
The answer to this would be C, functions.

42
00:02:22.490 --> 00:02:25.823
Roles, inputs and outputs, and metrics
are certainly part of every process.

43
00:02:29.376 --> 00:02:33.690
In which area would ITIL complementary
guidance provide assistance?

44
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:37.650
So this is talking not about the five core
books, but the complementary guidance.

45
00:02:37.650 --> 00:02:40.630
And this is an example of one of those
questions that's a multiple choice inside

46
00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:41.320
a multiple choice.

47
00:02:41.320 --> 00:02:45.450
So you have to evaluate 1 through 4 and
then pick the right pair.

48
00:02:45.450 --> 00:02:47.790
So the test makers get
a little clever with this.

49
00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:50.270
Obviously, it makes it
a bit more difficult.

50
00:02:50.270 --> 00:02:53.900
But in this case the answer
to this one is 1 and 4.

51
00:02:53.900 --> 00:02:57.270
Adapting best practices for
specific industry sectors is

52
00:02:57.270 --> 00:03:00.460
what complementary guidance
provides assistance on.

53
00:03:00.460 --> 00:03:05.656
And integrating ITIL with other operating
models such as project management or

54
00:03:05.656 --> 00:03:09.469
Lean Sigma or even ISO standards,
those types of things.

55
00:03:12.735 --> 00:03:16.720
Which is an objective
of service transition?

56
00:03:16.720 --> 00:03:19.938
Service transition is an entire stage,
not a specific process, so

57
00:03:19.938 --> 00:03:23.166
you're gonna be looking for
a rather broad answer in this example.

58
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:33.740
To ensure that service change creates
the expected business value, right?

59
00:03:33.740 --> 00:03:36.790
The other ones have obvious
other processes involved or

60
00:03:36.790 --> 00:03:37.980
other stages involved.

61
00:03:37.980 --> 00:03:42.420
To negotiate service levels for new
services, that's service level management.

62
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:43.840
That does negotiation.

63
00:03:43.840 --> 00:03:48.210
To reduce the impact of business critical
services outages on key services.

64
00:03:48.210 --> 00:03:50.110
That happens in service operations.

65
00:03:50.110 --> 00:03:53.410
And to plan and
manage entries in service catalogue, well,

66
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:55.260
that happens in service design as a stage.

67
00:03:55.260 --> 00:03:57.790
But very specifically it
happens in a process called

68
00:03:57.790 --> 00:03:59.730
service catalogue management.

69
00:03:59.730 --> 00:04:01.160
So you can eliminate the other ones,

70
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:02.875
leading you back to B
as the correct answer.

71
00:04:02.875 --> 00:04:05.810
[BLANK AUDIO].

72
00:04:05.810 --> 00:04:10.384
Which lifecycle stage ensures that the
impact of service outages is minimized on

73
00:04:10.384 --> 00:04:12.610
a day-to-day basis?

74
00:04:12.610 --> 00:04:15.160
We kinda got a hint on
the previous question about this.

75
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:18.681
It's service operations is
the lifecycle stage, right?

76
00:04:20.793 --> 00:04:22.552
It's dealing with
the day-to-day operation.

77
00:04:24.939 --> 00:04:27.903
Which is the best description
of a service catalogue?

78
00:04:36.157 --> 00:04:41.505
It's D, the part of the service
portfolio that is visible to customers.

79
00:04:41.505 --> 00:04:44.095
The other pieces here
are simply just wrong.

80
00:04:44.095 --> 00:04:46.994
A document used by IT staff to identify
activities that must be performed?

81
00:04:46.994 --> 00:04:51.915
Nope, we're talking about services here,
right, not activities.

82
00:04:51.915 --> 00:04:53.837
A list of all service level agreements?

83
00:04:53.837 --> 00:04:57.590
Service level agreements might be
referenced in the catalogue, but

84
00:04:57.590 --> 00:04:59.030
it's not a listing.

85
00:04:59.030 --> 00:05:00.875
The catalogue is not a listing
of these agreements.

86
00:05:00.875 --> 00:05:04.460
And a list of business requirements
that have not yet become services?

87
00:05:04.460 --> 00:05:07.590
Also, that's a business requirements
document, not an entire service catalogue.

88
00:05:10.484 --> 00:05:13.386
Which of the following is concerned
with policy and direction?

89
00:05:13.386 --> 00:05:19.420
A little bit of nuance in this question.

90
00:05:19.420 --> 00:05:24.600
All processes, all stages have some
concern with policy and directions.

91
00:05:24.600 --> 00:05:28.780
So perhaps the test maker got a little
bit full of himself here, a little bit.

92
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:31.830
So it makes for a good review,
perhaps not a great test question.

93
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:35.400
But it does define governance, right?

94
00:05:35.400 --> 00:05:39.210
Of course, every process at every
lifecycle stage has this concern.

95
00:05:39.210 --> 00:05:41.876
Governance is the one that has
the overarching concern with policy and

96
00:05:41.876 --> 00:05:42.381
direction.

97
00:05:45.730 --> 00:05:51.464
Which is an example of an operational
level agreement, an OLA?

98
00:06:01.509 --> 00:06:03.650
In this case the answer is A.

99
00:06:04.700 --> 00:06:07.900
A document that outlines agreements
between service providers in the same

100
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:09.090
organization.

101
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:10.690
Again, a quick reminder here.

102
00:06:10.690 --> 00:06:14.620
If you're the email service provider,
you have an agreement with the customers,

103
00:06:14.620 --> 00:06:16.480
that would be a service level agreement.

104
00:06:16.480 --> 00:06:18.830
But for
you to deliver your services as email,

105
00:06:18.830 --> 00:06:21.820
you need to have some other services
underneath you to help you.

106
00:06:21.820 --> 00:06:26.300
You need server services perhaps,
identity management services, so

107
00:06:26.300 --> 00:06:28.200
you would have OLAs with them.

108
00:06:28.200 --> 00:06:31.110
Operational Level Agreements with
those underpinning services so

109
00:06:31.110 --> 00:06:33.660
that you can deliver your
service at the right levels.

110
00:06:33.660 --> 00:06:34.973
So an OLA, as it says here,

111
00:06:34.973 --> 00:06:38.588
is an agreement between service
providers within the same organization.

112
00:06:41.629 --> 00:06:47.033
A known error record has been created
after completing diagnosis of a problem,

113
00:06:47.033 --> 00:06:49.410
but before finding a workaround.

114
00:06:49.410 --> 00:06:50.353
So you know you got something going on.

115
00:06:50.353 --> 00:06:55.820
You're just not really sure how to get
around it or even solve it, right?

116
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:59.076
Is this a valid approach to create that
known error record before you know really

117
00:06:59.076 --> 00:06:59.860
what's going on?

118
00:07:05.662 --> 00:07:10.406
You might be tempted to evaluate the no's
here since there's so many of them, but

119
00:07:10.406 --> 00:07:12.205
the answer is yes.

120
00:07:12.205 --> 00:07:15.225
The key to this is a known error

121
00:07:15.225 --> 00:07:18.405
record is really trying to
streamline incident management.

122
00:07:18.405 --> 00:07:20.351
So, just imagine a service call coming in.

123
00:07:20.351 --> 00:07:24.530
The service desk technician is saying,
hmm, I need to look into this.

124
00:07:24.530 --> 00:07:27.360
If you have a known error record,
you don't have to look as deep

125
00:07:27.360 --> 00:07:30.100
because the known error records say,
yeah, we know this is going on.

126
00:07:30.100 --> 00:07:31.780
We're not sure what we're
doing about it yet.

127
00:07:31.780 --> 00:07:36.187
But you don't waste time or the customer's
time researching something you know that's

128
00:07:36.187 --> 00:07:37.783
already under consideration.

129
00:07:41.189 --> 00:07:44.885
Which is used to communicate a high
level description of a major

130
00:07:44.885 --> 00:07:49.016
change that involves significant cost and
risk to the organization?

131
00:07:54.459 --> 00:07:58.974
This is almost the rote definition
of a change proposal, answer A.

132
00:07:58.974 --> 00:08:00.482
It's for the big things.

133
00:08:00.482 --> 00:08:04.765
Not every change needs
this level of rigor.

134
00:08:04.765 --> 00:08:06.507
A change proposal.

135
00:08:06.507 --> 00:08:10.435
The more standard kinda changes or
the more routine changes are RFCs,

136
00:08:10.435 --> 00:08:12.030
requests for change.

137
00:08:12.030 --> 00:08:15.010
But a change proposal is for
the big things, all right?

138
00:08:15.010 --> 00:08:16.287
Often generated by a service strategy.

139
00:08:16.287 --> 00:08:19.243
Going all the way back up to
the top of the life cycle stage.

140
00:08:21.696 --> 00:08:24.514
13, which person or
group is responsible for

141
00:08:24.514 --> 00:08:27.760
agreeing service targets
with the service provider?

142
00:08:35.622 --> 00:08:38.110
This was also kind of a little
bit of a flakey question.

143
00:08:38.110 --> 00:08:40.170
We're talking about
the customer in this case.

144
00:08:40.170 --> 00:08:43.370
The service provider has
agreements with the customer.

145
00:08:43.370 --> 00:08:46.883
I can make an argument that you could,
as a service provider,

146
00:08:46.883 --> 00:08:49.529
be making agreements
with suppliers as well.

147
00:08:49.529 --> 00:08:51.522
So find this a little bit flaky.

148
00:08:51.522 --> 00:08:55.010
What we're getting at here, what they're
trying to get at here with the question.

149
00:08:55.010 --> 00:08:56.513
And let's take this learning away.

150
00:08:56.513 --> 00:08:59.473
Is that there is an agreement between
customers and the service providers.

151
00:08:59.473 --> 00:09:01.715
And that agreement's called
a service level agreement.

152
00:09:05.259 --> 00:09:08.390
Which of the following
is true regarding value?

153
00:09:16.566 --> 00:09:19.190
From our treatment of
this topic in our show,

154
00:09:19.190 --> 00:09:21.720
you should have gotten this one right.

155
00:09:21.720 --> 00:09:24.170
It's a, Value is defined by the customer.

156
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:27.278
The phrase, the customer is always
right may not be completely correct.

157
00:09:27.278 --> 00:09:34.662
But the only opinion that matters when it
comes to value is the customer's opinion.

158
00:09:37.136 --> 00:09:40.560
Software and technology are examples
of which of the four Ps?

159
00:09:47.529 --> 00:09:51.710
Software and
technology are rolled into the products.

160
00:09:51.710 --> 00:09:53.047
Acronym there for the P there.

161
00:09:53.047 --> 00:09:59.019
You'll remember the other ones are people,
partners, processes, and products.

162
00:10:02.745 --> 00:10:04.546
Which is the main reason for

163
00:10:04.546 --> 00:10:09.181
a service provider to understand
the five aspects of service design?

164
00:10:09.181 --> 00:10:12.783
This is the stamp mnemonic
that we talked about.

165
00:10:18.559 --> 00:10:20.856
And again,
it's just reinforcing this idea.

166
00:10:20.856 --> 00:10:22.188
B's the correct answer.

167
00:10:22.188 --> 00:10:26.645
It's just reinforcing this idea that
solution design is not the same as service

168
00:10:26.645 --> 00:10:27.685
design.

169
00:10:27.685 --> 00:10:29.976
And service design must
have an holistic approach

170
00:10:33.672 --> 00:10:37.730
Which is the correct set of steps in the
Continual Service Improvement approach?

171
00:10:39.745 --> 00:10:41.700
This is just rote memorization as well.

172
00:10:52.545 --> 00:10:53.913
The answer is d.

173
00:10:55.909 --> 00:10:57.516
I think you might have gotten
this answer fairly quickly.

174
00:10:57.516 --> 00:10:58.764
It's certainly reinforced during the show.

175
00:10:58.764 --> 00:11:04.280
That you always start with, why do we
even care about this, what is the vision?

176
00:11:04.280 --> 00:11:08.273
So hopefully you started evaluating d
pretty early as you went here, right.

177
00:11:08.273 --> 00:11:13.540
And you need to start with that before
you start baselining where you are.

178
00:11:13.540 --> 00:11:15.620
And where you wanna be is,
why do we even care?

179
00:11:15.620 --> 00:11:16.730
So it starts with what is division?

180
00:11:20.040 --> 00:11:23.830
Which three types of metrics support
continual service improvement?

181
00:11:29.462 --> 00:11:30.300
I'll give you a hint.

182
00:11:30.300 --> 00:11:33.900
If you get this one wrong, you get a red
stapler and an office in the basement.

183
00:11:36.872 --> 00:11:39.630
It's c, technology, process, and service.

184
00:11:39.630 --> 00:11:42.950
I made the joke about the TPS
reports alluding to that movie.

185
00:11:42.950 --> 00:11:45.720
Maybe you haven't seen it,
it's called Office Space.

186
00:11:45.720 --> 00:11:47.720
So for those who haven't seen it,
that was a lost reference.

187
00:11:47.720 --> 00:11:50.010
But if you haven't seen it,
there's a hole in your life.

188
00:11:50.010 --> 00:11:51.450
You must watch that movie, yeah.

189
00:11:51.450 --> 00:11:54.840
Anyway, the answer is technology,
process, and service.

190
00:11:54.840 --> 00:11:56.204
Your TPS metrics.

191
00:11:58.834 --> 00:12:01.144
Which part of Financial Management for
IT service.

192
00:12:01.144 --> 00:12:03.599
Deals with predicting and
controlling income and

193
00:12:03.599 --> 00:12:05.643
expenditure within the organization?

194
00:12:05.643 --> 00:12:09.728
We talked about the ABCs
of financial management,

195
00:12:09.728 --> 00:12:13.850
accounting, budgeting, and charging.

196
00:12:13.850 --> 00:12:17.230
This is focused on budgeting,
that process or
